Robert Oppenheimer is just perfect. The soundtrack is definetly one of the best in the history of cinema. The Sound FX and the VFX is the best I ever saw and heard.. Christopher Nolan is amazing! This movie is definetly worth a watch.

Just for the shake of clarity and context, this is my first time watching a movie in IMAX. Oh boy was it worth it. Christopher Nolan's ability to extract every piece of acting excellency from his actors shined once more. Cillian Murphy gave his absolutely best performance yet, and Emily Blunt quite literally stole the third act, at least until the final scenes with RDJ. Technically wise, the sound department deserves every oscar it can get, from original soundtrack to mixing and editing. These people should be put besides the word "Extraordinary" in the dictionary. The cinematography was what I expected - dark, blue centered with lots of variety - given the fact that it's a Nolan film after all. I don't really remember any other time when I left the movie theatre and couldn't speak for like 10 minutes. I really couldn't explain what I've seen. Although a Tarantino fan for years, Nolan made me jump ship after this incredible masterpiece. It won't really surprise me if Oppenheimer gets 10-11 Oscars. It really deserves it. I really hope this is the time for Nolan to finally get his long awaited oscar as well.

Review_Title: When this movie will be listed in the top 250 movies of all time!!!
Review: After watching this movie, I couldn't say a word to express how much this movie was AMAZING, every second was meaningful, it was a 3hours movie but I didn't feel that I watched 3 hours I had the feeling that I wanted more !!!

An excellent beautiful masterpiece. The steller cast gave all to bring alive one of the most important events of our history. Cillin Murphy, Robert Downey was phenomenal. And not only him, each and every performance were at the top of their game. Nolan provided us with an opportunity to witness history. Three hours went by like it was nothing. Watch it with an audience, and this masterpiece will make you feel something different. In the end, you start to think, the weight of our actions as a human, the lives everything, you start to re-evaluate all.
The Movie, The Perfection. Nolan never disappoint us.
The movie was incredibly well done...for the first two hours. The last hour could have been written out as post script in the credits.

Review_Title: The most important film ever made
Review: The most important film ever made. After each viewing - by now I have the third behind me - this opinion solidifies. The exceptional director Christopher Nolan once again succeeds in projecting onto the big screen, with incredible attention to detail, unprecedented narrative structure and groundbreaking audiovisual design, the themes that have accompanied mankind since time immemorial and that make us ourselves a projection screen: Betrayal, death, time, love, the thirst for knowledge and progress. If Christopher Nolan has always based his previous works on these themes latently and sometimes individually, in Oppenheimer he unfolds them in a bundled and cumulative manner, questioning them anew throughout the film and thereby constructing them anew. Oppenheimer is a film that revitalizes, even reanimates, the institution of cinema, which was believed to be dead. The scenes in which the atomic bomb is tested and its dropping on Hiroshima is "glorified" in a speech by Oppenheimer are among the best that cinematic art has ever produced. The final section leaves one stunned, thoughtful, and at times disturbed. And that is exactly the task and the unique selling point of a movie theater. A mixture of biopic, horror film, courtroom drama and thriller - tightly packed and intricately knotted as only a Christopher Nolan is capable of. Oppenheimer is a film that society needed. After countless superhero and other CGI-drenched films in recent years, Nolan's 'Opus Magnum' is both an aesthetic delight and an existential challenge for our gray brain cells. That's exactly where the important questions burn themselves in after the viewing: Why is man trying to extinguish himself? What is progress worth at the expense of human lives? And how the hell did the British director manage to translate such a brute production into picture and sound?

Review_Title: Go and watch it, but dont expect too much.
Review: Huge Nolan fan here, but I was expecting more. More engaging history, a trial? He commited a crime? I didnt get that, I needed to chek goggle to know why this movie spend so much time in the trial. Was the trial a third of Oppie life?

I work as an professional editor so from my point of view it was a terrible long movie but funny enough it still was almost too short to tell the full story.. They should and could easily have made it into a series with 5-6 episodes instead of trying to forcefully edit a crazy amount of dialogues from one scene to another - and with no breaks and pauses between the scenes for most parts. We only get the pause to digest the huge amount of fast pace-dialogues when the bomb is about to blow up.. I suspect that the movie was originally longer, and that they were ordered to trim it down to meet the cinematic requirements.. - Or maybe Nolan just lost his touch? Tenet was a complete disaster and know this? Someone working close to him needs to "check him" and tell him to maybe take a step backwards and keep it more simple.. More is not always better.
Loved the movie and watched it to the end without blinking.
Another masterpiece from the master himself, Christopher Nolan.
As a firm appreciator of Nolan's filmography, but also as a huge history buff, I was very excited to see Oppenheimer, ready to relieve a similar experience to when I first watched Dunkirk.
After hearing review, opinions, and feedback on the movie following the hype of its release, I gave it a watch which I was planning to do anyway.

Review_Title: Oppenheimer: A Masterpiece of Cinematic Brilliance!
Review: Oppenheimer is an extraordinary historical drama that captivated me from start to finish. The production's attention to detail in recreating the era of the Manhattan Project was impressive, transporting the audience to a pivotal moment in history. The acting performances were exceptional, with each character fully embodying their role and bringing a depth of emotion that kept me engaged throughout.

Review_Title: One of the greatest movie ever
Review: I am waiting for this movie in 2 years and I watched it my experience is all time greatest movie ever when I watching movies and series for enjoy but you are not enjoying this movie it is a imotion for you I am pretty sure that is a Oscar winning movie. If I am director of this movie it is my greatest time to me I am proud of me but it is a one of greatest director of history Christopher Nolan movie he is a legend of unexpected and mind-blowing movie I am pretty sure all Christopher Nolan odians are watching the movie and I am saying for odians if you watch this movie you are legend thank you.

Review_Title: An insightful biopic about the inventor(s) of the atomic bomb.
Review: I have to give Nolan a lot of credit: he is one of the few directors that always manage to fill the theater. The film is beautifully shot and highlights a lot of issues from American politics during the war time, together with some questionable choices that were made, in the name of putting an end to World War II. The director managed to portray really well the moral dilemma that a lot of scientists that worked on the H Bomb felt, realizing that they basically created a mass destruction weapon. There are never particularly gruesome images, but the editing together with the soundtrack, really highlights the terrible consequences that this invention caused. This movie has an incredible sound design, and there are some sequences that are just breathtaking. Nolan always delivered technically competent movies and he is unique in his genre: the practical effects on this one are absolutely jaw dropping.

Review_Title: Nolan Strikes Again With Another Masterpiece..!💥
Review: OMG..! It Took Just 57 Days And Zero VFX For Christopher Nolan To Create Another Masterpiece This Time... The Characters, The Plot, The Storyline OMG! I Just Can't Express It.. But Will Say I'm Glad That I'm Still Alive In Nolan's Era Of Making Masterpieces..! After TENET I Was Desperately Waiting For Nolan's Another Masterpiece And On July 21 My Gosh He Delivered It With OPPENHEIMER! I Usually Say To The People That To Understand Nolan's Masterpiece You Have To Watch It At least Two Times.. That's Not Complain That's The Compliment Of Nolan's Artwork..! Moreover The Cast Was Iconic.. Will Just Say Go And Watch It..!

I am surprised at the interest in this film. I doubt that most americans know who oppenheimer is. We can't find florida on a map. Of course the ads started over a year ago and the tie in to the barbie opening helped. No one wants to be left out of an "event". As for the film itself, it's long. The person across the aisle checking the time didn't make it shorter. And it doesn't really focus on dropping the bombs, but on robert oppenheimer's dilemma with what he had wrought. Because his ideas were not popular in the early 50's, a very scary time in the usa, they did all they could do to shut him up and discredit him. As for the actors, hats off to robert downey, jr. He steals the show. But like the movie, you get tired of him, too. So go, join the crowds and you can tell your friends you saw oppenheimer. Knock yourself out.

Review_Title: Sometimes, older less known movies are much better
Review: Oppenheimer is long and boring, editing is confusing mixing 3 periods, that sometimes you don't recognize, which is before which one.

Review_Title: A Thought-Provoking Glimpse into History and Humanity's Ethical Dilemma
Review: "Oppenheimer" is not simply a tale of the most prominentt physicist during World War II; it is a portrayal of America's past, present, and future. Skillfully illustrating the ideological divisions between the left (communists) and the right (loyal Americans), the movie reminds us that history not only recounts the past but also explains our present.

What a journey! Christopher Nolan takes the audiences on a trip to the core of humanity. There is a lot of characters and dialogue which could easily get boring but on the contrary Nolan uses soft and hard elements combining them with such a mesmerizing way. Oppenheimer is an immersive experience with masterful usage of music, sound and other effects creating a symphony of soft and hard qualites. The balance of black&white and color elevates the story. Acting is suberb. Cillian Murphy is like an atom bomb of an actor: has a cool exterior but inside there is fire like no other! I was blown away by this modern masterpiece. 10/10.

I saw many movies during my life but not one was for me good enough to write an Imbd review. This movie has everything a good movie must have and even more than that. It is a biopic as great as it could be and mostly even historically correct. But for me a citizen of Eastern Europe it also has an essence of understanding of the great danger that the atomic bomb is. The movie uses no CGI and show real explositions of bombs and it is better than what any CGI could make. It is also very philosophical in its thinking about the threat that the bombs make. But most importantly the actors from the main Cillian Murphy to others like Emily Blunt and Robert Downey jr. Are all just as wonderful as they could be. This movie is a masterpiece and a must-see.

I may consider myself lucky to be alive to watch Christopher Nolan
Works which get better by years.

Review_Title: A Masterpiece of Intellectual Brilliance - Oppenheimer (2023)
Review: As an avid fan of historical biopics, Oppenheimer left me utterly mesmerized and profoundly moved. Directed by the unparalleled talent, Christopher Nolan, this film delves into the life of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the brilliant physicist who led the scientific team that developed the atomic bomb during World War II.

The life and times of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the brilliant physicist and central figure of the Manhattan Project, have always fascinated me. Needless to say, the movie surpassed all my expectations and left me absolutely awe-struck.

It felt like a very long trailer, not a movie. I don't think there is a conversation in the movie for more than a few minutes. Every scene wants to have you surprised, and honestly, it felt ridiculous after a while. Disappointing storyline. It rather failed to depict Oppenheimer as a real person and scientist. Nolan pictured him as an absolute hero. The conversation around quantum physics and nuclear physics in the movie was a bit shallow and short. There are a lot of great movies and series based on the work of real scientists, such as A beautiful mind, Chernobyl, or Imitation Game which explain their research and achievements with a simplified language for the audience and build the movie around that. The movie was very nationalistic and patriarchal. Just because he's American, there is a notion in the movie that he was the best in his field then. At the time that Einstein, Planck, Schrödinger, and Heisenberg were alive. And the most frustrating part was the representation of women. Drunk, mentally unstable, and angry at all times. It became a pattern in Nolan's movies, I think. All his main characters are men surrounded by dozens of more men. Usually, put one or two women at most in them.

Review_Title: The Pinnacle of Nolans Directorial Talent
Review: Whilst not a fictional sci-fi adventure epic, Nolan has turned the dial even further in this films composition, framing and pace.

Oppenheimer is less of a movie and more of an experience. It tells the story of the man who was the head of the Manhattan project, and what his life was life before, during and after the creation of the atomic bomb.

At first glance, the film feels like a rushed draft, attempting to captivate audiences with elements like Einstein, just for his namesake, Gödel's cryptic appreciation of trees, and Florence Pugh nude scenes - all without much depth or context.

Absolute banger by Christopher Nolan. It's just not a movie it's a sensation, the point it tries to make about chain reaction is justified by the experience you get from watching the movie. This movie frequently touches upon the fact that now mankind truly has the power to destroy itself. From stunning visuals to real like sound effects, this movie is a masterpiece of this generation.

Review_Title: Masterpiece! One of the Best Films I've Seen!!
Review: I had high hopes for this film, but it far exceeded my expectations. I highly recommend seeing it in IMAX, because it is visually stunning. On any screen it's still a masterpiece. There were so many stories that could have been told about Oppenheimer, but the way they told the story was so respectful yet captured so many important aspects of his life. With all the controversy, complexity, and mystery that surrounds this story, be it politics, ethics, or science, this film artfully layered it's scenes with a deep understanding, using metaphors and parallels that left me reeling with contemplation. There are so many layers, that this film can be a completely different movie depending upon how much of this story you knew before, yet still leave you dumbfounded by how beautifully these messages are delivered. The cast is nothing short of magnificent. Christopher Nolan is one of my favorites, but this may be his best yet. It's been more than 24 hours, and I'm still mind blown over how good it really was!

Review_Title: One of Christopher N. best movies to date.
Review: Other then interstellar and inception, I can genuinely say this is one of his best movies hes made so far. The amount of detail put into the movie was amazing and I love the film/editing effects he did to convey or portray a setting or time or place. It was a long movie, 180 minutes of runtime but honestly when it was over I turned to the person I was with and told them I wanted to see it again and they said the same thing. Also we couldn't help whisper to each other at parts because sometimes i can be a little tough to follow with all the historical figures. Would recommended everyone go and see it to see the dilemma he lived with. He did the right thing but he also created a much dangerous world.

Review_Title: Nolan stole lightning from the gods and used it to create this movie!
Review: It's perfect in every aspect, the greatest Nolan masterpiece to date and contender for best film of all time. Genuinely that good. Don't be surprised if they walk out with most awards for film in the next year!
Watching Oppenheimer, specifically in IMAX theatre was tremendous. Especially those sparkle effects, were actually the best for IMAX experience.

Review_Title: Decent movie, althought very time consuming
Review: Although Cillian Murphy's performance was great and the fact that many known actors take part in the movie, (most of them you may recognize as you watch this movie), I simply think that the length of this movie is a huge gamechanger. Personally i have a short attention span and i found that the story doesn't captivate you enough to keep you entertained throughout the movie. Either way i would recommend you to watch the movie so that you can understande the "hype" behind it. If you are someone who gets bored and distracted easily i would advise you to choose a day where you are ok with the fact that you are going to spend the whole afternoon inside a theatre.

Don't go watch it for the explosion, it'll be anticlimactic and you'll have to endure 2 hours of fantastic acting to get there, with another hour of continuous monologue to follow. It's one of the first bombs of its kind, not necessarily the biggest. An opening statement wouldn't go a miss - that it is all based on fact or an artistic representation of events, who the characters are and the role they play, which was muddy water some times.

Review_Title: "I am Become Death, the Destroyer of the Worlds."
Review: In a compelling fusion of biography, hisotry, and cinema, "Oppenheimer" proves once again that Christopher Nolan is an unwavering cinematic innovator. Dedicated to his craft and unconstrained by techonological boundaries, Nolan creates an intimate yet expansive narrative that is as explosive as the atomic bomb itself.

Review_Title: Like attending a 3-hour long, heavy college lecture that requires significant mental effort to get through
Review: Don't expect to be entertained while watching this movie. This film might inform you on the life of Robert Oppenheimer and might even stimulate you intellectually, but not in a fun or engaging way. It demands careful attention all the way through, with about 80% of the movie being heavy dialogue, the contents of which are hardly discernible without subtitles. Perhaps I went into the theater with the wrong expectations (and after Tenet, I probably should have known better) but I didn't expect to have to absord and retain so much information in order to not get lost at some point in the movie's 180 minutes long runtime.

Review_Title: If this is the future of blockbusters count me out
Review: To me it felt like an exceedingly long film trailer. Short scenes, constant soundtrack, whirlwind storyline.

Review_Title: The Best 3 hour film I've seen
Review: This film was incredibly interesting with amazing actors with Cillian Murphy taking main lead of this 3 hour film was incredible since he took kinda a lead in Peaky Blinders I knew Oppenheimer would be a success with him. Also nice sound and visual effects clear and crisp you felt as if your were in the film you felt involved lots of great knowledge especially if your a history nerd or just love a good 3 hour film this one is the one for you so this film is recommended it's a 10 out of 10 for me. Enjoy it with friends or family or even alone it quiet a film good job Christopher Nolan you definitely did well.

Review_Title: Awesome RDJ performance as Vindictive Admiral Strauss
Review: Wow where should I even start the movie began with depressing , wicked young J Robert Oppenheimer in college days in Europe, the way Nolan has captured cillian Murphy in mind boggling way at sometimes he seems careless to the consequences to his invention and sometimes the way he was so distraught with the consequences of his invention is very inventively captured the moral dilemma , geo political evolution , self discovery of Oppenheimer is not only very well portrayed by Cillian Murphy but was greatly captured by Nolan , from the very beginning the vision of atom particular that Oppenheimer sees is captured elegantly but one that got me by surprise was RDJ's Lewis Strauss or Admiral Strauss the way he was so poise , elegant almost throughout the movie then until he was not I won't reveal much but I will say his character is best describe by the Line used in movie by brilliantly played kitty wife of Oppenheimer played by Emily Blunt " The most vindictive are the one's who has more patience" so in last I will end this by saying that this is Christopher Nolan at his best all the actor's , crew has done fabulous job this is the movie to watch of the year.

Only Nolan can do this mix. When you talk about the atomic bomb and explain the complex physics of it's manufacturing in a such a simple way you have to be Christopher Nolan. But actually the movie is not about the bomb it's about the era of the world war and specifically the scientists and the conflict they suffered when one of the most revolutionary inventions turns into a lethal weapon that will kill hundreds of thousands or more. With the outstanding performance of cillian murphy as usual and the magnificent cast in every single role. The most surprising was Robert Downey Jr he was on fire the best role in his entire career so far. To sum up it's the perfect movie with the perfect director with the perfect cast with perfect soundtrack.

The incredible layering of the film, complimented by the awesome A lister cast- straight veterans in the field to newcomers with jaw dropping talent, this movie has it all. I think Cillian Murphy as Oppenheimer is a strong contender for the 2024 Oscars, while Downy Jr's Lewis Strauss deserves an equally well revered nod.

If you're looking for major explosions and an action packed film, this is NOT it. This is practical effects, amazing dialogue and good view on Oppenheimer and his life and the history of the atom bomb and the moral quagmire on the impact on humanity because of it. Thought provoking and the realization that you can be the smartest man In the room but you have people who want to discredit that. Only reason for not giving it at 10/10 is because the run time. You can feel it towards the end. The run time is worth it however to make sure that you get the entirety of Oppenheimer's life from the start and post WW2.

Even though the film is 3 hours, it seems relatively quick. People who are not very understanding of the political situation over the entire world during the II world war and the importance of what made physicists like Einstein, Bohr, Heisenberg etc important are very likely going to find the movie hard to understand. But if you don't come in the category just like me, prepare to have your mind blown. (Pun intended) It's the best ensemble of actors chosen with very conscious casting by Nolan. The "Can you hear the music" score is going to give you chills for sure. Everyone were amazing but Cillian, Downey, Damon and Blunt stole the show.

Long , boring , overrated
Nolan movies lately become disappointing with make no sense loud soundtracks, literally in the middle of the scene who every one talking and these soundtracks keep going for no reason , the first hour it's really good but more than half the movie just waiting for the bomb to drop and end the movie, every think going fast even with 3 hrs movie , u don't feel any felling for the characters because everything fast , I think Nolan should not use the same style in every movies and back to the old style like prestige and momento which more normal and fell more for the characters than his late movies like dunkirk and tenet , I gave the movie 6 because the beautiful shot and directing.

The actors and the acting performance were fascinating i loved cillian murphy in this movie but the sounds effect are an actor in this film too.no boring shots or momment nollan made somthing maybe with Nolan made something that some people could have. It is a boring thing for a beer. Something fun, visual and audio, right on the screen. It is one of the most important events of the well, and it is the making of the atomic bomb that changed the future of mankind. I advise anyone to see the movie in the cinema, you will regret it if you miss it... Because at a time when cinema was boring and people did not listen to cinema, Nolan came up with a movie that revives the spirit of cinema.

Review_Title: Slightly underwhelming, but still a good film.
Review: "Oppenheimer" is a captivating character study that sheds light on the life of the esteemed physicist, J. Robert Oppenheimer, while exploring the historical backdrop of the atomic bomb. The film's unique perspective focuses on the man himself, rather than solely on the bomb's development, cleverly reflecting its title's significance.

Review_Title: An absolutely dreadful, frustrating viewing experience
Review: I was so hyped for this film as I briefly lived in Los Alamos, New Mexico and have family involved in the US nuclear projects of the past. Seeing it today was an incredible letdown. I don't even know where to begin with the mess of this film.
Totally blown away by the message as well as the cinematic performance.

Review_Title: An exciting and illustrating documentary crafted by Nolan.
Review: Before I start, I'd like to say that I have been a huge fan of Nolan's work so fair warning that my review might be a little biased.

A masterclass in film making. Nolan has been consistently creating fantastic films for years and 'Oppenheimer' is no exception. Dialogue, cinematography and pacing are all on point. Ludwig's score is a perfect match for the aesthetic of the film. I have no doubt that Matt Damon, Florence Pugh, Emily Blunt and ESPECIALLY Robert Downey Jr and Cillian Murphy will all be up for awards, alongside Nolan and the movie itself. A future classic to be sure. As far as historical biopics go, a difficult and perhaps sensitive topic to tackle given its relevance today, but the messages and philosophy's shown through how the narrative is written and how history is represented throughout the movie is something I'm sure people will remember. 9/10.

Christopher Nolan once said that the first six minutes of a movie can define whether the audience stays to the end. He rolls up the curtains of Oppenheimer with an intro about a battle between humankind and the gods of Olympus. And right after that, starts a great game, that play your senses and mind. So yes, you definitely want to stay.

Review_Title: "Honey is not made for the donkey's mouth"
Review: I saw it yesterday, I'm still assimilating what I saw. All people left the theater hall so quitely without saying a word. The silence was loud.

Best movie i seen in last 5 years
Thank you Mr. Christopher Nolan because every movie you made it is legendary , this movie will gona writen in the history of the cinema.

This movie feels way to fast. There are no breathers except when they are detonating the testbomb, it was a welcome change of pace. The whole movie feels compressed and rushed. If this was an 10 episode (10 hour total) series like chernobyl this would have been phenomenal and maybe even out doing chernobyl itself. The story can easily do 10 hours of fotage.

This film is more than an achievement. It's ambitious, it's near flawless, and it's very gripping. The humanity Cillian Murphy and cast-mates bring to these characters is very rarely seen in film today. It was like you're there with these people taking part in everything that is happening on screen. From the hearings, the classrooms, the labs, and all the way to the Trinity Test itself, it feels like you're there. When that bomb drops, you feel the instant regret and fear that it brought to Oppenheimer and the rest of the scientists. This film has a lot of clear love and respect put into it. The practical effects feel more real than ever before and the tension never stops. Not even for a second. You will not leave this film feeling the same as you did when you first sit down. That's a promise.

Yes there were some good scenes, especially the test in the desert. The rest is a bit confusing and rough, but I got it, it's Nolan's style. I can feel that this movie was shot in 57days. I would have preferred Ron Howard or Oliver Stone as director. Nolan's movie is for sure 1hour too long. The last hour is not necessary. Since Interstellar I start really doubting Nolan's skill. He is for sure light years behind a real genius Stanley Kubrick. He should not even try.

Review_Title: Yawn-inducing and disorganized film that is also heavily dialogued
Review: The cover of the movie -- charismatic protagonist surrounded by atomic bomb effects -- looks intriguing and powerful enough to attract a wide range of audience from fans of Nolan to people who are interested in finding out about Oppenheimer and his biography.

I always rush to the cinema to see Christopher Nolans latest films. This is the best and biggest release of the year and it really didn't disappoint. The camera work, the stills all beautiful. Didn't have the luck of seeing it in IMAX because none of the cinemas in my town support it so that was disappointing for myself. Really have to pay careful attention to what is going on, the pacing was constant but tells a great story. The reference to JFK at the end I really appreciated after watching Kevin Costners masterpiece recently. Nolan said that he took inspiration from that film and Lawrence of Arabia, heroine turned to villain and victimised summed up Oppenheimer just like those films. Definitely got my moneys worth today. Go see it!!

As I settled into the dimly lit theater, little did I know that the next few hours would be nothing short of extraordinary. The movie's captivating storyline took hold of my senses, whisking me away to a world of magic and intrigue. From the very beginning, I was hooked, unable to tear my eyes away from the screen. The plot unfolded like an intricately woven tapestry, revealing unexpected twists and turns that kept me on the edge of my seat. Nolan's masterful cinematography added another layer of enchantment to the already mesmerizing tale, effortlessly bringing the characters to life. Each frame was a work of art, filled with breathtaking visuals that left me in awe. As the credits rolled, I couldn't help but feel grateful for the unique experience I had just witnessed, one that would undoubtedly stay with me as a cherished memory.

Review_Title: One of the best I ever watched
Review: You'll have to have your wits about you and your brain fully switched on watching Oppenheimer as it could easily get away from a nonattentive viewer. This is intelligent filmmaking which shows it's audience great respect. It fires dialogue packed with information at a relentless pace and jumps to very different times in Oppenheimer's life continuously through it's 3 hour runtime. There are visual clues to guide the viewer through these times but again you'll have to get to grips with these quite quickly. This relentlessness helps to express the urgency with which the US attacked it's chase for the atomic bomb before Germany could do the same. An absolute career best performance from (the consistenly brilliant) Cillian Murphy anchors the film. This is a nailed on Oscar performance. In fact the whole cast are fantastic (apart maybe for the sometimes overwrought Emily Blunt performance). RDJ is also particularly brilliant in a return to proper acting after his decade or so of calling it in. The screenplay is dense and layered (I'd say it was a thick as a Bible), cinematography is quite stark and spare for the most part but imbued with rich, lucious colour in moments (especially scenes with Florence Pugh), the score is beautiful at times but mostly anxious and oppressive, adding to the relentless pacing. The 3 hour runtime flies by. All in all I found it an intense, taxing but highly rewarding watch. This is film making at it finest. A really great watch.

Review_Title: Once you get into the film's Rhythm, its an amazing ride!
Review: As the story opens you discover that this is not a "begin here and end there" type of Drama. In fact, it seems to be flying all over the place in time and location. It takes the viewer a few rounds of this type of flashback, "flash-forward," "flash-middle" storytelling to get into the rhythm of this ultimately amazing film about the life of Robert Oppenheimer, who was the director the Manhattan Project that created and unleashed the Atomic bomb on the world, and who was later chastised severely for his early flirts with Communism and various social protests.

This movie was just amazing Christopher did an amazing job as always and made yet another amazing film and cillian Murphy did a mind blowing performance definitely getting an Oscar for this I just loved Oppenheimer aftermath reaction to the bomb definitely gonna watch it like 3 times in theaters, must watch movie in a large screen. Emily, RDJ, matt did an amazing job as support characters of course nothing less all of them are amazing actors but for me personally the Batman was my fav movie but now it has to be Oppenheimer so i definitely recommend all of you to watch it and have a 3 hour experience of a life time.
Christopher Nolan has given us The Dark Knight Trilogy, Inception, and Interstellar. However, his newest film about "The Father of the Atomic Bomb" might just be his greatest.
Christopher Nolan has brought us an amazing story once again, visually pleasing, as well as amazing acting in the movie. If you love history this movie is down your alley.

Review_Title: If Kanye West's "Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy" album was a movie
Review: A movie that just absolutely captures the importance of profound scientific and global affairs in a spectacular way. It was would be like if Kanye West's "Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy" album was a movie. Cillian Murphy puts on a virtuoso performance encapsulating the deeply complicated and contradictory life that Oppenheimer lived. The pace that the movie runs at is so intense and the music is used perfectly to capture that. The explosion of the bomb is so realistically filmed that you feel fully immersed in Los Alamos. The subtle themes of "The Fission" and "The"fusion" floated at the beginning of the movie is an incredible way to depict to the two separate courtroom like battles Oppenheimer and Strauss are involved in. Nolan has many great movies under his belt but this movie tops them all.
Well played by actors, ruined by the constant sound and music, let me tell you that i had a headache after the movie.

Review_Title: Nolan's Timing Fiasco: Biopic or Blooper Reel?
Review: Within the initial two hours of the film, we find ourselves navigating through a labyrinth of superfluous character introductions that seem to yield scant significance to the overarching narrative. A judicious recalibration of the storytelling, discerningly excising extraneous segments, could have undoubtedly remedied the pacing predicament, allowing for a more enthralling cinematic experience. Nolan's virtuosity in crafting intricate timing events is a testament to his filmmaking prowess, yet it's evident that his acumen encounters limitations when attempting to encapsulate the essence of a compelling biopic.

I think this was my best experience in the cinema in a very long time. I had the chance of watching it on 70mm and it was really staggering. I admire the team for making such a film about one of the most sensitive and important stories to be told. As a filmmaker myself; i know how exciting it is to make a film about true events and i know this are the hardest stories to tell. Moreover, the background score was beautifully done, it really achieved the emotional impact it was intended to put upon the audience, great score. I didn't expect nudity in a Nolan film,but i understand it was necessary to tell the story in a more sophisticated and realistic way.
Nolan has succeeded to create a different cinematic expirience. An unconventional one.

It's hardly the most exhilarating subject, the development of the first nuclear bomb, but Nolan does a superb job of moulding the fascinating story into a journey through history, personalities, and struggles that keeps you enthralled for the 3hrs, which for me glided by very smoothly.

Cillian Murphy is one of the best actors of all time and this movie proves that. His acting is amazing, i think if they got anyone else to play Oppenheimer this movie would not be as good. Warning it can be very loud at certain times. When you finish this movie it puts a whole new perspective on dr Oppenheimer. Christopher nolan is an amazing director and this movie is a masterpiece. I wouldn't recommend it to kids under the age of 13-14 because it does get pretty adult at some moments and it can be very psychological and difficult to understand for some younger viewers. But if you can you need to watch this masterpiece.
In the forces of nature, duality exists. This law governs our humanity. It is the catalyst by which we create...and by which we destroy.

I'm 77 saw this with my 20 year old sun; we haven't discussed this yet because I have to wade through the details, and my hearing is what it was so I will have to revisit when it hits cable. But I do remember the aftermath of much of the happenings here; a long passed away friend who was in the Navy during WWII made a remark during a club meeting where Memorial Day, the 4th of July or another patriotic date was current. He stated that it was clear had we not dropped the bomb, that the carnage in Japan would have been unspeakably abhorrent. It would have been door to door, and person to person. Also Japan dropped Pearl Harbor on us at a time when our entry was not at all inevitable. What struck me what how so little has changed in (in)human nature, especially in politics in general and DC in particular. As an aside, I noticed that "James Woods" was an executive producer; there happens to be another James Woods with IMDB and I was pleased that IMDB shows it was the same James Woods whose roles I have enjoyed for so long. I know that as of January 2, 2023, he has not been hired for an acting job since a voice gig since a voice acting job in 2019 due to his outspoken conservative views. Kudos to him. He may have empathized with Dr. Oppenheimer. Welcome back.

"Oppenheimer" is an extraordinary cinematic masterpiece that deserves all the accolades it receives. With its captivating storytelling, brilliant direction, and impeccable performances, this movie takes us on an immersive journey into the life and mind of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the father of the atomic bomb. The film skillfully delves into the complexities of his character, exploring his genius, conflicts, and moral dilemmas. The attention to historical accuracy and the meticulous recreation of the era adds authenticity to the overall experience. "Oppenheimer" successfully blends science, history, and human emotions, leaving audiences both educated and deeply moved. It's a thought-provoking and powerful cinematic achievement that lingers in your mind long after the credits roll. A definite 10 out of 10.

Review_Title: Cillian Murphy was great, shame about the other main casting choices
Review: Emily Blunt acted overly vexated throughout, Robert Downey Jr was not able to deal with the subtle changes in his character later in the movie and ultimately he became dastardly and laughable, Florence Pugh deserved better and spent 60% of her 5 minutes screen time with no clothes on including a bizarre scene where she and Murphy are naked sitting opposite each other on arm chairs (as one does..), going all austin powers and covering their private parts strategically, Matt Damon was not terrible but I found him unconvincing (especially his delivery of '.. this is the biggest thing to ever happen in the history of the world!!' was most disappointing), Casey Affleck acted like he was an imperial officer in a Star Wars movie
This movie is truly amazing I mean it's very hard to break it down into words

Review_Title: Thought-Provoking Film with Oscar Potential Faces Criticism for Explicit Content and Age Rating Concerns
Review: It's possible that this movie could win an Oscar. The subject matter impressed me, and on the whole, it was a great film. However, I did have a problem with the explicit sex scenes. It bothered me more than other things, even if some people might not think it's a big deal.

Well what I can only describe as a meandering pule of un-chronological dross and an aimless recreation of fake history with nothing much other than exaggerated caricatures of real people for the sake of making grey characters black and white. A cinema audience will notice every overdramatic often ear piercing rumbling sounds of a bomb interjecting conversations thayprovide a means of prevention for the audience falling asleep over uninspired dull and meaningless dialogue that holds itself literally without any poetic candor or quotable value. The laughable overacting from Matt Damon paints a one dimensional picture of your stereotypical army general, seemingly mature audiences will be enraptured by the somehow oscar worthy performance of Cilian Murphy woodenly staring into the camera for 3 hours without uttering a word. The characterless blasé, second rate to Zimmer score plays at events so eventless as a man getting out of his car or going to the toilet, drowning out unintelligible lines from actors who focused too much on sounding American as opposed to coherent. Blunts tragic and forgettable performance of a hateful wife could not overshadow the pathetically small explosion that despite having a multimillion dollar budget was smaller than the real thing.

If you see one film this year, or this decade, let it be Oppenheimer. This is one of the greatest films of all of history. This is a deep film too. I am broke, taking money out of my IRA to pay a bit off of the credit cards in order to see this movie. I needed to see this film opening day in IMAX. I am glad I did. Very important film. It is rated R, but I would still recommend you see this movie with your older children supervised. That is if they are well behaved. This is a movie that you don't take a restroom break halfway during. Go before. Don't buy a large soda and popcorn. I never do anyway. But I sometimes buy a double Jack and Coke at AMC Theatres. But this film I decided not to get a drink. No distractions.
Perfect Movie. All aspects. Political, social, emotional, historical everything is good. Except One scene where Bhagavad Gita quote with romantic shots. Totally disappointed.

Oppenheimer is a film that will stay with you long after you've seen it. It is a powerful and moving story about the creation of the atomic bomb and the man who created it. The film is visually stunning, with a stunning recreation of the atomic bomb test and emotionally powerful, with a deeply moving portrayal of Oppenheimer's inner turmoil.

Well damn i just watched and I don't know what to say it was so fascinating and confusing and scary it the same time its ture when i heard that guy in tik tok when he say that when u get out of the movie confused and wanting the bathroom and having a really wired crush on Cillian good god I don't know what to write amazing acting and i was silent all the movie in amazement and awe I really don't have words that movie was 3 hours and was so quick I really can't comprehend wooooooooooooooow thank you for making a masterpiece o_o damn i just don't have anything more to say thank you so much masterpiece.

This review comes from someone who gets into the cinema with a VERY few basic facts about Oppenheimer and how he's the father of the atomic bomb. That's all I got in my brain when I got into the cinema. Im not a science physics lover and I only know two physicists in the movie and that is Neils Bohr and Albert Einstein, nothing more. And I only know the name Heisenberg from Breaking Bad shows so if you're empty headed like me when you're about to watch this movie, I gotta say go learn some of the characters in the movie first so you will not be a little confused and mixed up with the characters like me.

Review_Title: Nolan the undefeated GOAT of modern film-directors!
Review: In a world where legendary filmmakers clash, Christopher Nolan once again emerges as the victor, maintaining an undefeated streak with his latest masterpiece-a biopic that delves deeply into the psyche of an extraordinary character. Nolan's brilliance shines through flawlessly executed editing, captivating sound mixing and the enthralling interplay among complex characters.

Okay...I wanted to like it more. However the first 30 minutes was a bit too much of Oppenheimer's mental visions and esoteric political bent. After that, it got better. Still be prepared for numerous time hops that can be a bit confusing, something to identify the timeline would have been helpful. I appreciated the moral dilemma, but also know that one needs to find comfort in the greater good.

Review_Title: The best movie of the century ! best bio pick.
Review: "Oppenheimer" is a captivating and thought-provoking cinematic masterpiece that delves deep into the life and mind of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the brilliant physicist and key figure behind the development of the atomic bomb. The film brilliantly explores the moral complexities and ethical dilemmas that arose during the Manhattan Project, showcasing Oppenheimer's internal struggle and the weight of his decisions. With stellar performances, meticulous attention to historical accuracy, and evocative storytelling, "Oppenheimer" offers a compelling narrative that invites viewers to reflect on the profound impact of scientific advancements on humanity's trajectory. This movie is a must-watch for history enthusiasts and those interested in the intersection of science, ethics, and human nature.

There's much that's praiseworthy of this movie. Illuminating a key, forgotten figure whose brilliance helped end WWII, exploring his very human side, and reminding us of the damage wrought by the McCarthy hearings, all good. The fears the physicists had, that the atom bomb would ignite the atmosphere and burn the world, and then their very real horror of what they'd wrought, also good. The context, established so well in Matt Damon's general, that the American people (as well as the other allies) were desperate to end the war, is made clear. The effects are all that you expect from modern moviemaking.

Review_Title: Movie for Netflix not for Cinema, Disappointing
Review: I had high expectations as it's Christopher Nolans movie and I am a big fan and admirer of Christopher but what is this. This movie made me sleepy in Cinema and I didn't enjoy it at all. These kind of movies are for Netflix. Except one explosion scene there is nothing in this movie. Are we paying the ticket to see bunch of actors sitting in a room and questioning Dr. Oppenheimer. I don't know what people like in this movie. Actually the taste of people regarding movies has spolied. A stupid spider man movie takes 8.8 rating. Rather I will watch Memento Movie instead of Oppenheimer. Very Disappointed.

" Oppenheimer " is a cinematic triumph that deserves all the accolades it receives. It's a rare gem that combines artistic vision, exceptional performances, and thought-provoking storytelling into an unforgettable movie-going experience. If you're a fan of cinema that challenges and inspires, this is a film that you absolutely cannot miss. Prepare to be swept away on a journey of emotions and artistry that will leave you breathless and in awe.

I think this is second or third best movie from Nolan. The non linearity in storytelling is the typical Nolan thing. If you are Nolan fan ,this movie will keep up the hype. And the acting has been exceptional. Cillian really nailed it and so rdj too. The visuals and background score makes it quite good. If you compare it with other Nolan movies you might find this weak but in this genre you can;t do much .Emily Blunt have some strong scenes. Second half is too paced and good. First half is good and slow but you might not get some stuffs if you miss those conversations in first half. I would have given 9.5 but since i m Nolan fan so i am bit biased here.

Review_Title: Nolan proves you can still make such movies!
Review: Nolan has truly outdone himself with "Oppenheimer," proving that his previous works like Dunkirk, Tenet, and Interstellar were merely warm-ups for this three-hour, R-rated, adult drama filled with intense dialogue. It's a nostalgic throwback to the time when Hollywood used to create such thought-provoking movies. This might even be the last of its kind, or perhaps studios will learn from the underwhelming summer movie slate and start taking more risks instead of sticking to formulaic focus-group-approved films.

The movie had beautiful shots throughout the movie as well as mini storylines that kept you well entertained Even up to the three hour mark. With all the movie shorter than ever It is good to see a film that can entertain people for hours on end. The storyline that was presented in this movie was incredible and well worth every second. The soundtrack was breathtaking and amazing to see in theaters. The storytelling aspect of the movie was able to capture you the entire way. The bomb seen was beautifully done and away, not seen before in explosions. I truly great film that explores the history of the atomic bomb.

This movie was brilliant. An absolute masterclass in how to direct a proper movie. If you are trying to decide whether to watch Barbie or Oppenheimer, take an IQ test, if it's above 110 go and see Oppenheimer, if it's average, go and see Barbie. Cillian Murphy was excellent. Don't go and see this movie if you are expecting explosions, this movie is about the politics surrounding the Manhattan project and what followed after the bomb was dropped on Japan. I honestly couldn't recommend this movie enough, if you're a movie fan, you must see this, it will have you fixed on the story, hanging in very suspenseful sentence. It is in my top 20.
What a great morality play. Oppenheimer saves the world while simultaneously putting it on a course that could one day destroy it.

Review_Title: If you enjoy Nolan and the film Air
Review: A group of men in suits in different rooms arguing about the ethics surrounding the invention of the A bomb. The music, sound and absent of sound are marvellous depictions about the stresses of working on projects that are bigger than the ego. Yes the A bomb was awful and catastrophic but perhaps it served as a greater good invention required at the time. Was Oppenheimmer a good man? No one is truly good but just as in all businesses especially government, people can make you just as much as they can also break you. The symbolic ripples throughout, matched with the fast paced dialogue and glimpses of foreshadowing will leave you pondering did I just watch another rendition of Macbeth?

Review_Title: Decent movie spoilt by over loud and intrusive background music/effects
Review: This could have been an excellent movie with a star studded cast and stand out performance by Killian Murphey. However on a film largely dependent upon dialogue I can't understand why the editors felt it necessary to have constant background music (it never stops throughout the movie) which was discordant and painful to endure. At times it was so loud that hearing what was being said was impossible and even at it quietest it made comprehension difficult.
I'm an engineer whose loved physics his whole life.

Such a disappointment. The movie is too long and dwells on the security clearance issue in a melodramatic and disjointed way. What did we know about Oppenheimer at the conclusion? He was a tortured soul. He liked women and was a genius. Did we feel compassion or sympathy for him? No. The over arty editing didn't help, neither the jarring score which punctuated scenes. The audience is left none the wiser about the 'Father of the bomb' nor his motivation or humanity. Clever word play and lingering shots of Murphy wearing the signature wide brimmed hat won't make up for the deficiencies. Such a shame.

Review_Title: Nolan, at his absolute highest of his capacity.
Review: '...its a brilliant artistic creation and its faithful to the book.' - Kai Bird

An incredible movie a one from his kind actually, the cast is incredible and I want to prise Robert Downey Jr. I saw a lot of people talks about Cillian Murphy I agree that his performance is great but Robert it's from another world I think he will get an Oscar for his performance.

Who was Oppenheimer? Seemingly, we see an ordinary man, a student who wants to succeed and be somebody. That his knowledge is studied even after him. To leave something to humanity that would help them develop further in the future. Fight diseases, famines, wars. Basically, what is the goal of comprehensive science? The development of civilization and its progress. Helping the individual as a human species to rise. What did J. Robert Oppenheimer with his work? He brought death. How and why? To stop more deaths. Did he regret his invention? Not at all. He enjoyed the glory, he gave new energy to humanity. That can help. Tomorrow that weapon can be used to deflect an asteroid that would destroy us. He regrets that he placed his child in the hands of those who did not use that knowledge for the benefit of humanity. To the powerful, for whom human lives are just numbers, and those who realized what they had done are - cry-baby, as one character said. Here, in addition to all that, we see a classic biographical film. Very well woven, with a few flaws. Some of these are the large presence of music in scenes, where it is placed in scenes where someone is talking. It is constantly heard. When characters like the main one are walking, they enter the room and music is there. No need. That's what wasn't needed on that scale. Another minus is that the start is a bit slow. Not meeting him at the university, which was really cool, but all that getting into the story around the Manhattan Project. I get the impression that Nolan did this on purpose to inflate the film to a three-hour running time. Like the old epic classics. But this film, when compared to today's commercials that overwhelm us, can comfortably be called an epic classic despite some flaws. Many singled out the absence of women as one of those. They are even in some way well depicted considering the time and the work the main characters in this story deal with. The tension is brilliantly portrayed by the anticipation of the atomic bomb test and what happens afterwards. After that, you have one scene as well as the ending itself, which can comfortably be called the best in the film. The scenes of testimony before the committee and congress are reminiscent of courtroom dramas and thrillers. Cillian Murphy rocked this role, he portrayed Oppenheimer perfectly. He might even win an Oscar. However, Robert Downey Jr. Stole the show. A great performance of his character, Strauss. I think that if he doesn't win an Oscar now, he never will. It would be completely deserved. Emily Blunt is also good in the scenes where she is represented more. She did a great job on this. Matt Damon, smarmy, brings the humor. Gary Oldman is excellent in that one scene. Rami Malek, very small role and silent. All in, a movie that you will love if you are a Nolan fan and love this genre. I can say - the best movie of the year so far.

Christopher Nolan just stamped his foot print into cinema history as an all time great. It is as if each film he's made has just been a building block leading him to conduct this masterpiece. Oppenheimer is Nolan's finest work. Murphy delivers a sublime performance, reaching a threshold very few actors ever will. Next year's Oscar statue can be put into escrow for Cillian. Nolans three hour plutonium dense genius-of-physics, magnum opus does for the atomic bomb what Spielberg did for sharks at the beach. It seems Christopher Nolan has turned in a tour de force that has vaporized the competition. In fact, Scorsese's 'flowers of the killer moon' may be the only threat of a rival for best picture. However, that may be the toughest act to follow since Einstein's theory of relativity.
The elements of our universe are truly miraculous. Tremendous insightful masterpiece.

Oppenheimer inverts the expectations for what the audience thinks the plot is in the most exceptional fashion. One might assume that this movie is about the atomic bomb and the impact *the bomb* had on the world stage, but it's really about the people, specifically Oppenheimer and the US government. Nolan's decision to omit the dropping of the bombs in Japan was the right choice, as it really demonstrated this film is about Oppenheimer, not the bomb. As such, the ending tied everything together into a neat bow that summed up what the bomb really meant in the evolution of modern society beyond the point of material destruction.

It definitely didn't need to run for 3 hours but for the most part, I was really impressed by this film. I didn't find my mind wandering or thinking "how much longer", the storytelling pace was on point and gave you plenty of detail of how things developed for Oppenheimer. It was fascinating and the size of the cast and big names impressive. Maybe I missed something but it took 3 years to collect enough material to build the first bomb then suddenly after the successful detonation, 2 new bombs are ready to go. How? The film depicts the unfortunate outcome of working with Government, it's not about you but it's all about them.

Review_Title: Captivating, Intriguing, and difficult to stop watching.
Review: With the amount of dialogue in this movie, I was worried it would feel long and boring. That being said, the movie was made in such a way that kept me engaged the entire time. The soundtrack was amazing, and the transitions between the scenes coupled with the beautiful views of explosions and particles (not using CGI) kept myself holding my eyes open with the fear of blinking for even the smallest amount of time. I do not think the acting could have been any better, and the tense buildup to the trinity test - as well as the final heartbreaking line said by Murphy at the end - was constantly gripping my full attention. In almost every scene I was wondering what would happen next in terms of Nolan's artistic capabilities, and never was I disappointed. When a historical drama can keep you glued with your eyes open the entire time, despite the fact that many of the events portrayed are known to us today, it's very difficult to rate it below a perfect score. The impact of this movie is still making me ponder with wonder about the life of Oppenheimer. This movie is a perfect example that a depiction of one real man can leave people in awe, admiration, and deep thought.

Don't get me wrong, Christopher Nolan did a great job making this movie. It was a suspenseful, historically important movie. However, I am very disappointed that a movie that probably has cost a lot of money to make, did not even bother to check whether the Dutch (scene which was shot in Leiden) actually made sense. It was in fact, not Dutch, but German. This, especially considering that the timeline was during WW2, is shameful. WW2 was a difficult time for the Dutch, of which survivors, including my own grandma, are still alive. Older generations can take offence to this mistake, and it is just very sloppy.

How one can make a 3 hour movie about the man running the Manhattan Project, about the brilliant complex physics, technology and the earth-shattering moral dilemmas entailed in putting it to use; and end up mostly making a political soap-opera is at least surprising and at best a missed opportunity.

Review_Title: So how is the most anticipated movie of the year, Oppenheimer..?
Review: So how is the most anticipated movie of the year, Oppenheimer..?
Best movie of 2023 for me -

Review_Title: A movie that has moved me deeply, and has changed my perception of the modern world.
Review: Where can i start. This movie adresses a very sad and emotional topic, that i think really connects to our modern world and the future of it. The threat of nuclear weapons is existential, and is always in the back of our mind. The portrayal of this in this film is incredible. Not to speak of the incredible cinematography and writing by Christopher Nolan. The way that the explosion is set out, it represents the mid point of this film rather than the end. It is a very powerful moment, and the sounds and images are just incredible. Nolan also intertwines three timelines, before the bombings of japan, the present (set in the time of these bombing), and after them explaining the repercussions that Oppenheimer faced and the way that the US dealt with this. The ending is even more powerful, and even received applauds from the audience. An incredible movie that i think is one of the highlights of this decade.

Review_Title: A film about a real person, not an action movie or a cinematic sci-fi
Review: Unlike Nolan's other films, this is to watch alone from home with a glass of whiskey.

This was a tough one because I would consider myself a film nerd. I have been for 20+ years. So, was this film a high level of filmmaking? Yes. Was the acting in this film top notch. Yes! Was the writing, costume, set design, editing all good? Yes. I don't mind movies that are dialogue heavy. This was definitely that type. I had trouble giving this an 8, but I figured it did mostly everything great...however, just didn't captivate me like I was expecting. If I'm being honest, it felt like a 7.6 or so. Which I consider really good.

Amazing movie, loved the film. Cillian Murphy with an oscar deserving performance, everyone did well in the movie. RDJ did so well, loved his role in the film. The music by Ludwig was so so good, the build up for detonation was so good with his music. The detonation was really good, the way Christopher Nolan gave the build up towards the detonation was top notch. This is pure cinema. One of my all time favorite film! In one particular scene, everyone moved to the front of their seats, the heart raced so hard, bet no one ever felt like that while watching a film. I highly recommend this film to everyone!

Review_Title: A gem of a cast brings the Manhattan Project to life, but then....
Review: It is three hours long, but for a history buff like myself who knows his material, Christopher Nolan's Oppenheimer is absorbing from the start. Most impressive is the star-studded cast who bring the characters to life. Cillian Murphy is perfect in the titular role; Matt Damon is a believable General Groves; Robert Downey, Jr inhabits the part of Lewis Strauss; Tom Conti is transformed into a genial Albert Einstein. The only disappointment is Gary Old man, who had been so excellent as Winston Churchill but here plays Harry Truman like a caricature. Besides the cast, the editing is also amazing. The whole movie plays like a jigsaw puzzle, with different parts being assembled as each piece is put in place at different parts of the puzzle, until the whole picture is finally complete.

A truly exceptional film composed of equally exceptional components. Great storyline & linkage, quality performances, ethically daunting and disturbing for all the right causes, with powerful scenes that deliver at all levels. On top of all, Nolan's unique directing, scenography and soundtracks set the bar high as f*, as usual. The movie highlights the ever lasting dilemmas of our society relating to personal choices, politics and war, weapons of mass distruction and the real possibility of humanity's entire existence hanging on a thread. I only hope that its prophetically placed ending won't come to pass.

Review_Title: Spectacular And Amazing But Not Entertaining
Review: I'm an admirer of Nolan's movies. He casts or selects someone for his movie with utmost care, which he has done the same for this movie as well. Particularly C. Murphy, he is the best choice to play Oppenheimer's character. He lived in the character and has given his best. R. Downey & M. Damon were great supporting actors too. Nolan's display of Oppenheimer's life was spectacular and at times were outstanding. The bombing scenes or the trauma scenes or the flashback scenes, they were outstanding for sure.
I was looking forward to this film, since I am a huge fan of Inception that I found really clever and thought provoking.
This review contains spoilers
Oppenheimer delivers on its expectations, though in a different way than I was expecting.

Nolan's direction skills are on full display in this film, as he masterfully blends historical accuracy, emotional drama, and stunning visuals. The film was shot in a combination of IMAX 65 mm and 65mm large-format film, including sections in IMAX black-and-white film photography, which gives it a unique and immersive look. The film also features a score by Ludwig Göransson, which adds to the tension and suspense of the story.

As per usual Nolan delivered a knockout punch with his latest movie Oppemhiemer. Seeing the movie on the day of the release was one of the most impactful moments in my cinema reviewing life. Dynamic and full of contrast, Oppenhimer perfectly captures the rush, fear, and anticipation of the Manhatten Project. The movie is ae easy 9/10 purely for the sake the trailer let the movie on to be more linear. The movies only downside is the constant cuts can sometimes be hard to follow, however, those aspects allow for an abundance of re-watchability. Every actor gave a stellar performance and this movie is something that is both entertaining and educational into the psychological break down Robert Oppenhimer experienced.

Review_Title: a short story of the destroyer of worlds
Review: I think it's spectacular for a biopic film. Maybe, you can say '' i think it's boring cuz this film is 3 hours. ''. But we shouldn't forget about this isn't a movie just contains action. This is a film of the destroyer of worlds, someone you can't easily get into his mind. Moreover, the film has also managed to reflect the events in an objective manner. Maybe, Nolan should use florence pugh much important role than this and court scenes should be shorter than this but i can say, you should watch oppenheimer. In the film, we are seeing the classic nolan technique that named by me '' playing with time like a wizard :-) '' by the way.
Why One Piece Is Better Tan Naruto or other anime?

The volume in the Imax was set so high i missed half the dialogue, especially the mumbly Oppy. If he had much of importance to say I missed it and it made following the jumping about in time even harder to follow. EXCEPT Matt Damon. His enunciation is clear as a bell. He knows how to speak. Wish other actors had been to the same school. It is probably a much better film than i experienced, the visuals are stunning and ther is some science mingled with the human stories. So, disappointed. It would be so easy for directors to ensure their films are audible and for actors to address their audience.

A very important movie because it tells the most important story in the history of mankind, which is the story of the nuclear bomb, but it does not tell the story of the bomb, but rather the one who invented this bomb, who is Robert Oppenheimer, who played the role of Cillian Murphy, who gave an Oscar performance And he gave us wonderful psychological acting scenes, and the other actor, Robert Downey Jr., who gave the best performance in his career, Matt Damon, Emily Blunt, and all the actors performed their roles wonderfully, but the defect of this movie is that it is complicated. In explaining the nuclear bomb and during the talk of the scientists it will make you somewhat distracted and the second negative is that I was waiting for a movie by Nolan such as Interstellar or Inception, but I found myself in front of a biographical movie with the fingerprint of Christopher Nolan But I enjoyed the movie even though I expected more from this movie and it is definitely the best movie of the year so far But it includes some boredom and suffers from the long time in the elephant.

Review_Title: Three average movies, combined into an unsatisfying film.
Review: So the first third is so strangely cut and with such poor dialogue that it feels more like a trailer for a film. The second part is a classic action packed "let's build a thing!" Which at least gives us a moment of satisfaction from finally seeing the bomb do its thing. Ultimately disappointing as it's a bit of a fizzer. The final part is just a government bureaucratic drama that was so boring and pointless I wanted to die.

There was nothing i liked about this movie especially the thing youre waiting for. The dialogue is hackneyed, performances campy and forced, Florence Pugh mostly. Super contrived everything. Wanted to love it, wanted to learn. Just felt like i was seeing a writers room laying out forced scene after forced scene. The weirdest thing was how everyone looked, the make up, Cillian Murphys skeleton body... And who wants to see another courts case trial movie? Thats what this is if you didnt know. A trial where they flashback to the events that led them there like the flicks where someone is getting interrogated. Boring. Boring. Boring.

Review_Title: Oppenheimer " took me on top of Everest to celebrate cinema
Review: OPPENHEIMER "is a cinema that takes the audience to the top of Everest to celebrate cinema. Chris is a mind-blowing filmmaker who never talks about stories in simple language. He has a seriousness towards people's time & thoughts. The way he tells stories in every film is a virgin vision of visual language & narration I saw nine times continued watching

Chris making a movie where Cillian is playing the leading role is something I never knew I needed. I rated this movie 10/10 even though there were things in dialogs I didn't quite catch up with or understand but just as Chris says for his films: Don't try to understand them, feel them and boy did I feel this one because my head was spinning afterwards. Though I am sure I will understand everything after a rewatch. Great movie, the cinematography was beautiful. Scenes where they zoom in Cillian's face and where we kinda see what was Oppenheimer thinking or feeling in some moments seriously made me terrified in a good way. We definitely need Cillian in more main roles in movies with a good director like Nolan and a good plot because this man deserves it. I watched many Nolan's movies and they never disappoint and this one just adds to the list. Give this man an Oscar already which he definitely doesn't need but deserves.
The movie:

The film was great maybe even perfect for the first 2hrs, the last hour was confusing and felt like it moved at a slower pace than the first 2hrs. However the Movie was great no matter the length, great characters and visuals, However the best thing about this was the music, just perfect. The movie Could be Top tier if I wasn't so tired after the movie, Oppenheimer is A great,cinematic, dramatic and visually outstanding Movie, that is only pushed down by its pacing. In all honesty the movie is my Second favourite Nolan film next to the Dark Knight. I will give the Movie a 8/10, worth A watch.

Review_Title: An absolute showstopper from Cillian Murphy
Review: Cillian utterly steals the show with his performance in this narrative heavy, fast paced drama. He portrays the emotional fragility and genius of a remarkably complicated man outstandingly.

Review_Title: I am become Death, the Destroyer of Worlds.
Review: First of all, I went to see this movie in IMAX and it was one of the best movie experiences of my life, but during the bomb explosions or the main character's visions it was too loud.

Review_Title: Worth seeing on the big screen. Better than Nolan's other recent stuff, but not perfect.
Review: For most part, the rendition of dialogue is finally improved in this film compared to the last few Nolan outings. We're not yet back at Memento or Prestige fidelity, though, in dialog or the rest of the film generally. Those were his seminal greats, in my opinion. Sorry, but even The Dark Knight was not a truly great film overall if you deleted Heath Ledger from it.
I'm still collecting my thoughts after experiencing this film, Cillian Murphy might as well start clearing a space on his mantle for the Best Actor Oscar.

Review_Title: I thought it was great but they should've ended it near Trinity
Review: The movie isn't what I would call dramatic, but it does portray Oppenheimers life fairly accurately.

Another nolan disaster, the last three of his movies were totally illegible, mumbling dialogue overlaid with loud annoying music that completely destroyed what may have been great movies Interstellar being a perfect example, mc connaughty's southern drawl was the icing in the cake there!! Entire movie totally ruined. Oppenheimer, from what i have read in many quarters suffers from the same NOLAN ADDICTION!!.

Oppenheimer is without a doubt the best movies of the year. Not only is it the best movies of the year but it is one of the greatest movies of all time. This movie is a cinematic masterpiece with breathtaking visuals and sound design. It is a 3 hour rode that flies by very quickly. Bot a single second is wasted, every moment serves a purpose. This movie also has excellent performances throughout especially when it comes to Robert Downey Jr and Cillian Murphy. The side characters are also incredible. Oppenheimer is not only a biopic, it is also a character study that goes deep like the likes of taxi driver. It allows you to explore oppenheimer and his thinking in a very detailed way. Nolan has done it again! 10/10.

A movie that was undoubtedly amazing and undisputed. We did not feel bored throughout its three enjoyable hours, which was full of many scenes and details as if you were actually living that era in history. The movie was really the pinnacle of cinematic creativity, and is truly considered one of the rare cinematic icons, especially since it was made by the genius director Christopher Nolan, who writes his name in golden letters in history, And let's not forget the rest of the wonderful crew, without exception. I can say that the film deserves to compete for the Oscars this year, if not the best ever.

This movie is a masterpiece and one of the only movies deserving of the 10/10 rating. The movie is paced very well and keeps you engaged throughout with the dialogue. The soundtrack is absolutely phenomenal and helps you to fully immerse yourself into the world crafted by Nolan. There are moments in this film that will really have you questioning your reality, which is what puts this movie above so many others. It successfully manages to portray true horror of nuclear warfare without the use of violence or gore and does not overly rely on VFX.

Review_Title: What else can be said, it's a masterpiece.
Review: Oppenheimer, directed by Christopher Nolan, is a masterpiece of a character study, building up suspense and most importantly dread like no movie I have ever seen. What I found so particularly amazing about it is the fact that you know what's coming, you know what the titular man and character releases and yet the buildup to that faithful test keep you on the edge of the seat.

Review_Title: Now I am Become Death, Destroyer of Worlds
Review: Originally, I wrote a review earlier this year for Nimona where I dubbed it as perhaps, "my favourite film of all time." Without trying to demean its impact, it isn't even the best film of 2023 anymore.

Hamilton (the musical) is special for many reasons: amazing sung, racially diverse, phenomenally written. But most of all, because it provided our current generations a modern connection to and humanization of the founding of our nation. Though it is about their primary author, the musical is as much a subtle honorific of the Federalist Papers and their philosophy, which in turn shaped the Constitution and our whole way of governance.

Review_Title: Lots of talking and caring about the government goons.
Review: I don't have strong feelings about this movie. So if I criticize or praise it's not too deep. My eleven year old nephew wanted to see this movie but it's rated R.
The speech after Hiroshima... the way it was captured, and the way that Cillian played... it was a real cinematic experience which I'll never forget.

Review_Title: Missed opportunity for his next film.
Review: I struggle to see why Nolan chose to make this film over anything else. I'm a big Nolan fan, but feel cheated as this film has been completely over hyped. Good performances, but it's very difficult to follow as it keeps jumping. Yes technically it's great and got great reviews, but have the reviews been based on the film or the past record of the director. It this didn't have Nolan's name attached to it would it have really been given 5/5. My friends and myself felt completely underwhelmed by this film and it is too long.

Review_Title: The unnecessary sex scenes ruin and otherwise very good movie 9/10
Review: The unnecessary sex scenes ruin and otherwise very good movie 9/10. We get about 2 hours and 57 minutes of physics, political intrigue, bureaucratic management, and 3 minutes of soft core porn that does NOTHING to move the film forward. As a student of physics, it was great watching a movie try to explain some of the problems in physics to the general public. Oppenheimer had a very high IQ, but along with that came some of his faults. It wasn't necessary to show these in bazaar way of him having sex in government meetings.

Oppenheimer review
Let me start with the positive aspects of the movie first:
1. The cinematography of the movie was very good
2. The soundtrack of the movie was very good
3. The acting is great, obviously. I especially liked the acting of Cillian Murphy and RDJ.

Review_Title: "The world is changing. Reforming..." Oppenheimer is Cillian Murphy's moment.
Review: On Friday 21st July, I experienced Christopher Nolan's Oppenheimer in stunning 70mm IMAX.
A film for self-reflection, a film about humans.

Review_Title: A brilliant film that some may find "boring"
Review: Nolan's dialogue is always intriguing, and it is probably the best it ever was in Oppenheimer. However, heavy dialogue films may not be someone's "Cinematic experience", and therefore I would advise some individuals to watch the film at home.

Review_Title: A masterpiece, but not quite perfect.
Review: Saw it in IMAX 70mm film and it's staggering in that format. Truly one of the most incredible movie experiences I've ever had. Visually it's beautiful, and the audio in an IMAX theater has to be heard (and felt) to be believed.

I went to the movies to see what's the hype is all about.
