Review: I genuinely appreciated that this movie built layer upon layer within itself. Excellent film with an excellent cast. I was engrossed the entire time, and it didn't feel like I was in the theater for three hours.

Acting10/10 , story writing 10/10 , soundtrack 1000/10 , cinematography 10/10
This was the first time I enjoyed a biography film this much it was an overwhelming experience and tbh I never wanted the movie to end
The soundtrack is so complexed and takes you to another world with mixed emotions and feelings
A movie that makes you wonder was Oppenheimer a good citizen or just the devil in sheep's clothing.

Oppenheimer was a brilliant physicist who made significant contributions to the development of the atomic bomb during World War II. His leadership as the scientific director of the Manhattan Project was crucial in successfully harnessing nuclear energy for military purposes. However, the ethical implications of his work cannot be ignored. The devastating consequences of the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki raise important questions about the responsibility of scientists in the pursuit of knowledge. Oppenheimer's later involvement in advocating for nuclear disarmament demonstrates his recognition of the destructive power he helped create. Overall, Oppenheimer's legacy is complex, representing both scientific achievement and the ethical dilemmas inherent in scientific progress.
Oppenheimer is really a great movie, mainly because it is based on a true story and shows us how atomic bombs were made and the history behind it, who made them and why.

The way ive been immersed in the movie theater with the tremors of the explosion was a really cool expérience. Even if the film is 3h00, that was interesting. The story is very good btw. This is obviously a real story about the man who created a bomb against Japan. I dont really have the habit to see a long film like Avatar 2, so I...I fell asleep a little at the end. The director, Christopher Nolan, is very clever because he made the explosion without ANY CGI. And I find it very ingenious. The color of the whole movie is clever too. It can go from black and white to an abrupt change to color in color: it corresponds to Oppenheimer's subjective experience and constitutes the majority of the film. The other is black and white. It's a more objective view of history, from another point of view. One last thing, I do not put 10 stars because nothing is perfect

I really like Nolan, he is one of the best! Unfortunately, I fall on media hype and went to cinema with few movie junkies such as myself. Yes I didn't expect entertainment in this genre, but after 30min I literally waited movie to finish. It is super difficult to follow, boring and annoying conversations.. Mat Damon was a joke together with Einstein 😂😂😂😂 and Josh H. I do not know what to say..
I really excited something more interesting and all I got this boring never ending movie.. I would agree with some random comment: this movie is like you are watching movie trailers.. never ending movie trailer 😂😂😂
I was actually laughing on some super serious moments.. that can only say how I lost connection with the characters and plot
A wonderful journey of thought, a wonderful experience.

Review_Title: Oppenheimer: Morality and war, the shadows behind science.
Review: If you are an enthusiast of scientific history, or you have knowledge of general culture, maybe when you hear the word "atomic bomb", two concepts come to your mind, Hiroshima and Oppenheimer, of this last concept I will talk based on the film with the same name, which is directed and written by Christopher Nolan and starring Cillian Murphy as J. Robert Oppenheimer, the American physicist known as the father of the atomic bomb, due to his participation in the secret American war project called the Manhattan Project.

Review_Title: Oppenheimer: A Glimpse into the Enigmatic Scientist's World
Review: Oppenheimer, directed by the renowned filmmaker Christopher Nolan, takes us on a riveting journey into the life and mind of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the brilliant physicist who played a pivotal role in the development of the atomic bomb during World War II. While the film has its imperfections, Cillian Murphy's portrayal of Oppenheimer is nothing short of extraordinary, making it a must-watch for history buffs and fans of Murphy alike.

Review_Title: A Must-See Film: Oppenheimer Delivers a Cinematic Masterpiece
Review: Oppenheimer" is nothing short of a cinematic masterpiece that deserves every accolade it receives. Director [Director's Name] has crafted a mesmerizing work of art that delves deep into the complex life and moral dilemmas of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the brilliant scientist behind the Manhattan Project.

Review_Title: Title: "Oppenheimer" - A Masterful Fusion of Science, History, and Artistry
Review:
In my lifelong pursuit of the enthralling crossroads between
science and history, "Oppenheimer" emerged as the crowning
jewel of 2023. This yearning for intellectual exploration found
its zenith in the captivating narrative that chronicles the life of
J. Robert Oppenheimer, a brilliant yet enigmatic figure of the
20th century. The fusion of science, politics, and psychology is
orchestrated in a mesmerizing symphony by the accomplished
director, Christopher Nolan. His astute direction and attention
to detail bring an unparalleled depth to the narrative,
immersing the audience in Oppenheimer's world.

I think the implied idea behind is: Oppenheimer was not sure about the multi-chain reaction of activating a nuclear bomb will lead to the destruction of the whole earth. Nor he was sure about a nuclear war escalation and international multi-chain reaction after the US own their nuclear weapon. There is an impressive scene when a meeting is held to protest the releasing of the nuclear bomb in the WW2. And Oppenheimer, after such a very hard and uninterrupted time struggling himself, says something like: "If we human cannot see the power of the nuclear weapon ourself, we will never stop being so curious about its power. Sooner or later it has to be a bomb release into the battlefield, and its terrifying consequence will create a very strong deterrence. Fortunately, releasing two bombs in Japan did not destroy the whole earth, but it did destroy human intention to escalate and put the world into a nuclear war. As for now, we can have a beautiful Oppenheimer film to contemplate.

Masterpiece and unbelievable acting from all of the cast specially robert dawney jr and cillian murphy the acting is from another world the director is genius the scenes the picture was really amazing and unique overall I recommend to watch this at the cinema it's another experience you all should try. I want also talk about the many feelings that cillian murphy showed to me and his character as dr oppenheimer it was avery difficult,different and hard character to play he is unbelievable actor he shared with us many many of feelings and i think this movie will life for a very long time and will be one of the best historical movies we ever had..

Review_Title: Disappointing, but not for a lack of effort.
Review: This was a tough one to get through for me. The pacing and score of the film were unrelenting, and scenes were cut together with the same mentality of one who thinks music would sound better if we played the notes as fast as possible. Scenes of over dramatic intensity felt used to divert the viewer from something lacking in the film. To me certain scenes were so saturated with drama I wanted to pantomime the puking gesture.

Christopher Nolan has done it again, and this could arguably be his best screenplay to date. The motion picture is packed with a high-power dream cast including the likes of Cillian Murphy, Robert Downey Jr., Emily Blunt, Matt Damon, Jason Clarke, Kenneth Branagh, Rami Malek, Casey Affleck, Gary Oldman, and I could go in and on. The movie is a priceless time piece covering everything from quantum physics to US politics of the time. It gives one of the best depictions in cinema that I have seen of McCarthyism and the witch-hunts that dominated mainstream American politics in the late 1940's and 50's. And of course, it gives a very good account of the race to develop the first atomic bomb and the justification to use it.

I have seen most of Nolan's films, and this is unlike any other. This movie is not so much a mind bender as the likes of Inception or Memento, nor is it as visually massive in scope as Interception. Instead, Nolan chooses more subtle, but nonetheless marvelous, technical methods to tell the story. Namely, the different pacing between Oppenheimer's POV (color) and Strauss's (B&W) seems to be employed to show two things. One, Oppenheimer's POV moves in hard, quick cuts, showing both the urgency and brilliant speed with which his mind operated. Strauss's is slower, more calculated, showing his true nature (I won't spoil too much, despite it being a true story). Nolan is subtle with this choice, but it is extremely effective. Furthermore, his storytelling choices in major moments of Oppenheimer's life, make us feel as if we are personal observers, rather than the usual birds-eye view, a massive spectacle offers.

Oppenheimer is brilliant. The movie is so intense- 3 hours passed by for me (twice) without blinking an eye. The effect the movie has on its audience is profound. Sound track did complete justice. Seamless intertwining of two parallel storylines. Acting is just brilliant- Cillian Murphy shines like none. So do Matt Damon, Robert Downey Jr and Emily Blunt. The movie explores the political theatre of World War II and the following Cold War with such nuance. The final twist is superb. Christopher Nolan's movies are a gift to mankind. Oppenheimer has officially qualified to be my favourite movie of all times (until Nolan makes a better one..;))

"Oppenheimer" is a mesmerizing cinematic masterpiece that delves into the riveting life of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the brilliant scientist behind the development of the atomic bomb during World War II. Directed by the visionary filmmaker, this biographical drama transcends the boundaries of a typical historical documentary, offering an intimate and thought-provoking exploration of Oppenheimer's complex character and his moral dilemmas.

Review_Title: Nolan's first biopic is a masterpiece.
Review: This movie is such a departure from a standard Nolan film in that it is a true story. It is a story about how a group of people got together to change the world through science and maybe not for the better. The story that is told is very clear, there is a pre-Nuclear war world and a post-Nuclear war world. The US spent almost 3 billion in 1945 money on a single project that would shape the nature of warfare and it was done by some pretty awful people, most of all J Robert Oppenheimer.

It was a gorgeous looking thing and some terrific work by Robert Downey Jr and a whole host of other folks. Watching a 70 mm print made a big difference but it would sure be nice if people was bad hearing like me could actually get all of the dialogue.

It's really a disgrace what we, as a species, have done and are still doing daily to eachother. In my humble opinion, that is what this movie encapsulates so vividly that you can almost feel it around you for the whole three hours and after you're done watching it even though the events from it happened almost eighty years ago. The acting is superb, but I would do him great disservice if I didn't mention the performance of Cillian Murphy who stood out above all others with his preparations and dedication to the job of playing the part of the man that was and still is someone who, at the very least, represents a figure that's polarizing beyond measure. Nolan managed to do it all over again.

Come on, after 1h30 I was hoping someone would shot Oppenheimer and the movie would end. This is way too long. It could have been an interesting movie of 2h (not saying good). Productors are lucky Nolan is directing and there is a very good cast otherwise that would be a complete failure. I believe this movie benefits from the social media factor where nobody thinks anymore and just repeats. A few "influencers" have manipulated the mass of zombies not thinking for themselves and now it is cool to see this movie and to brag about it. Well I left the movie after 2 hours. Too slow, I have better things to do with my life....
The best cinematic experience of recent memory for me. I am feeling very sorry for those who didn't like it that much, they probably couldn't feel what I felt when it's ended.

Review_Title: One of the best movie of 2000's
Review: Monstrous film, apotheosis of cinema, triumph of audiovisual, three hours flown as if they were 90 min. You can not help but be kidnapped by sensational dialogues, by the colossal acting performances, by the impeccable direction of Nolan, who in my opinion signs his best film.

Review_Title: The Masterpiece for those who grasp the greatness
Review: This movie may be 180+ mins, this movie may be of full on drama, this movie may have multiple time lines running parallely, this movie may not have a single VFX shot.
I usually like Nolans work. My favourite was Dunkirk. But this movie was way too long.

Review_Title: Fantastic with some things to note
Review: Honestly one of the best movies Ive seen in a while. While this movie is 3 hours it completely kept my attention throughout. The actors portrayals were also fantastic. Particularly cillian murphy's, RDJrs and Emily blunt's.

Review_Title: Great Insight into History by Nolan
Review: A Great Insight into History,How Nuclear Bomb was made and its implications on World Order,Diplomacy, Rivalry between Nations,Society,Economy,Politics. Cillian Murphy as Dr Robert Oppenheimer is obviously same as his name. Robert Downey Jr as Lewis Strauss was great. Florence Pugh as Jean,Emily Blunt as Kitty and short but powerful impact role of Rami Malek as David Hill was Hard-hitting. Matt Damon as Leslie Groves,Alden Ehrenreich as Senate Aide,Jason Clarke as Roger Robb,Kenneth Branagh as Niels Bohr played their rolls well. Overall Christopher Nolan gave great direction to it and Music too was good along with Effects. Glad I watched it in IMAX Laser!

Review_Title: Nolan's Unconventional Movie Structure Unveils a Powerful Message
Review: I admire Christopher Nolan's audacious decision to place the bomb test in the middle of the film instead of concluding with a grand finale. By eschewing the typical 'big bang' approach, Nolan artfully unveils the subtle yet crucial nuances of Oppenheimer's eventual downfall from grace. This unconventional narrative structure allows us to delve deeply into the complex issues that Oppenheimer encountered during the later phases of his illustrious career.

"Oppenheimer," directed by the esteemed Christopher Nolan, explores the life of Dr. Julius Robert Oppenheimer, a pivotal figure in history who played a crucial role in the development of the nuclear bomb during World War II. However, while the film boasts Nolan's visionary storytelling, I find it difficult to celebrate this particular biopic.

Review_Title: Amazing movie however you should know a little background before going to see
Review: Knowing Robert Oppenheimer and the Manhattan project background this movie was absolutely fantastic to me and exceeded my expectations! However, people who do not have an insight other than the scientist who made the atomic bomb this movie can be complex and hard to follow. Especially if you think it's going to be all explosions and madness. No it's about Oppenheimers accomplishment, challenges and complex life. It's a must watch just read a little on his background first to follow and enjoy better! The cinematography, the sound, acting, quality, and soundtrack were all excellent and a must see in RPX or IMAX. (I swear the room was shaking you can feel the explosions)
A truly special experience that was poorly interpreted by a great deal of people. Mine not be good either however I truly found this to be the best representation that I could think of.
Nolan has created a visual and aural masterpiece.

What Christopher Nolan achieves with this film is monumental to his catalouge. He proves that he can do more than an insanely complicated plot where you dont know whats left and what right. This film relies on well written dialogue and a dominating performance by Cillian Murphy. Accompanying that is a great display by Robert Downey jr who portrays Lewis Strauss, Downey Jr, shows what he is capable of in Oppenheimer, where Tony Stark is far away.
A great story pictured with excellent actors and superb audio-visual effects.

This is really overrated movie compared to nolan's other films. I did not understand the nudity even two times. The scenes are also not necessary and not important for the movie. So it feels me like someone told nolan to make a movie about the atomb bomb and he did it like that by highlight how america is great and all the others should be scared from them.

Review_Title: A (meta)philosophical, ethic, physical, artistic and historic masterpiece by Christopher Nolan!
Review: Tbh., this has to win every Oscar there is... Cillian Murphy is a genius actor and one of our generation's finest. The cinematography, the plot, the acting, the historic accuracy: just everything is perfect.

Review_Title: 3 Hours of High Tense Science and Political Drama
Review: Ngl, I was mostly excited for the Trinity Test, but the main focus of the film is about one man: J Robert Oppenheimer. After learning about his story, my expectations were high for this film. His communist political views, the Manhattan Project, and the security hearing which led to his downfall. This movie doesn't glorify about creating the bomb and dropping it on Japan, this movie is in the experience of Oppenheimer's perspective of his life. The movie is basically a biopic documentary and a character study of the rise of becoming the 'Father of the Atomic Bomb's to his downfall during the security clearance hearing trail. Everything about this movie is phenomenal from start to finished.

Review_Title: Just a long boring movie not a good documentary.
Review: Its a terribly long movie with a lot of noise, less of a storyline, far fetched from the truth and well its overhyped. Might even win an academy award but would never pay to watch it in theatres, might just watch it on Netflix if im too depressed. Have seen better CGI as well as documentaries on youtube videos. Expected a lot better from Nolan but maybe its the general public that hyped it up. All those people going to visit theatres to see this movie thinking of it as an exciting thrill or something, well you've got another thing coming since it sucks and so does Manyu claiming to be an exciting movie.

Review_Title: Didn't live up to the hype..
Review: Soo the movie was't bad. It's certainly a great movie to watch due to its great cinematography and actors such Murphy and Downey.

Really well shot, written and directed. Great acting from ALL cast. Excellent sense of suspense which ultimately leads to a fantastic movie that will be one to watch for years to come. I thought i would get bored as it was very long, i certainly did not. I didnt even look at my watch once which is incredible for me. Cilian Murphy plays an epic role and he captivates his viewers. Robert Downy Jr is on point as usual.

Review_Title: Dull, Boaring and a waste of time
Review: I've had more fun having my teeth surgically removed and sucking on a lime straight after.

Review_Title: Good actors, boring and confusing story line :(
Review: Was at the IMAX Leonberg, Germany in the largest cinema in the world and watched the film there.

OK, let's start by saying I'm full of admiration for film makers and the work involved in putting together something like this. But it was just too long, too convoluted and too lacking in empathy for me.
I respect Nolan's craft but I am not a fan.

This movie really sucks. Script, dialoges, editing, directing, music, everything but the acting for which I gave the three stars. It's like watching a 3-hour trailer that makes no sence, full of pointless supposedly smart sayings, and jump scare loud sounds. Time was in the quantum realm, never really knowing when each scene took place, in which I really wondered what did I miss to interpret the punch line.. I really wonder how it passed production after editing. I hope Christopher Nolan comes back with Sci-fi action film, where he seems to thrive. Best part was Albert Einstein who looked like a 1800's Ottoman pasha.

Review_Title: Don't fall for the 'Nolan hype', this isn't nearly his best.
Review: Spoiler-free breakdown (not that you CAN actually spoil it since you probably read about Manhattan Project by now).

Review_Title: Oppenheimer: A Trailer Triumph, A Film Fumble
Review: The movie feels more like a documentary than a feature film. When I watch the trailer, I get a completely different impression than from the movie itself. For me, it wasn't worth a trip to the cinema, even in IMAX. There were a few segments that kept me awake. While some find the film too complex, I found it more tedious than intricate. If this were shown in a university class about the history of the atomic bomb and politics, I'd give it a 6 out of 10. The film delves too much into details. Nonetheless, I'd rate the movie's marketing a 10. They promoted it exceptionally well, but the movie itself didn't live up to the hype.

I always hated Nolan's movies, but the hype got me. I guess I'm no better than all the idiots populating Hollywood, but, in my defense, this is the last time I'll be fooled by the outright lie about Christopher Nolan being anything but a spoiled simpleton.

Review_Title: Stuff's overrated and released in the wrong era
Review: To be fair I already watched the excellent synopsis from Veritasium and others on youtube. If it were the 2000's and youtube wouldn't exist I would give this one an 8/10.

Talk about a movie that jumped around and around. I know what happened in history and even I was confused by what was on the screen. Movie is too focused on all the wrong things. It's jumpy. If you didn't know anything about history you'd be lost. Why were their 3 different timelines going on at the same time? Show one year - put up a title card of the next decade/year and continue. Break it into 3 parts. Doing 3 timelines was just stupid. Also would have loved to more of the science behind how he did it and not the white men in suits paying for the project. Director wants to show you all the pretty pictures with none of the story.

Review_Title: McCarthy witch-hunt of 1949, little else. Hard pass
Review: Turgid boredom that managed to suck the life out of the awe and brilliance of quantum discovery, portraying seminal theoretical psychists as lowly clerks, and focusing on U. S. commy paranoia. No soundtrack, just a wall of bass. Nolan utterly failed in script. Lighting too dark. No build of tension - you will forget you are there to see the inception of atomic bombs. Not even a courtroom thriller - just endless questioning of Oppenheimer in a room, and a complete fizzle of an atomic explosion. Acting fine, but I'm in the presence of Einstein and checking my watch!?! This should have had huge tension as Nazi's vs. Allies race - you'd hardly know it was WW2. As a warning about A. I., as Christopher Nolan said he had intended, then we are all doomed.

Review_Title: A message for Christopher Nolan fans
Review: This review is for the Christopher Nolan fans:
A biopic drenched in fiction which ended in a plot if which you can't tell what's based on facts and what isn't.

The problem with Christopher Nolan movies is, that no matter the premise, people will always enter the theatre with incredibly (and sometimes unrealistically) high expectations. I don´t think, many people would get overly excited about watching a 3 hour biopic about Robert Oppenheimer, but put Christopher Nolans name on it and it becomes one of the biggest blockbusters of the year. I am a huge Nolan fan as well but tried to limit my excitement as much as possible, remembering very well that in 2020, I left Tenet kind of disappointed because of my unrealitstically high expectations - even though it was overall a very good movie (after the second viewing that is). For Oppenheimer, it didn´t make it easier, that movie theatres were immediately sold out for days and initial critics (even the ones that were not generated by Chat GPT) were showering it with praise. I finally managed to get a seat in a rather small theatre tonight and have to say: Even with neutral expectations, this movie was a disappointment.

Review_Title: Boring. Wont recommend watching in theatres
Review:
This biography of J Robert Oppenheimer can be told in 1 hr 30 min max. It has been stretched for 3 hrs don't know why which has made this film very boring. Didn't expect this from Nolan. Instead of showing only dialogues in the entire film for 3hrs straight he should have added atleast some action sequence..
I thought that after the interval maybe this movie will pick up some speed but no it was only dialogues the entire time...dont know why people are liking this trash film. I was expecting something like interstellar or atleast some action sequence. Apart from all this boring stuff the cinematography was good as it was shot on IMAX and cgi wasn't used so if that is a good reason for you to watch this film you can go ahead but I wont recommend this movie to watch in the movie theatre, wait for it to come in the OTT.

Completely zero entertainment. There is no story at all. People are flocking theatres with hype created and at the end there is no single person who seems to have enjoyed the film. Some people who tell they liked the film are bluffing acting like intellectuals with reality being they are dumb *ss. Do your self a favor and skip this crap. Watch Paramanu which is 100 times better movie. Watch Paramanu which is 100 times better movie. Watch Paramanu which is 100 times better movie. Watch Paramanu which is 100 times better movie. Watch Paramanu which is 100 times better movie. Watch Paramanu which is 100 times better movie.

I really wanted to see this movie and saw it on the big screen. I was trying to figure out what was wrong with this movie the whole time while I watched it. Even after the first 40 minutes I had no idea where this was going. The storyline was so disjointed, bouncing back and forth in time sequences. This created a real lack of continuity in the telling of the tale. There was a potentially great story to tell here, but it just seemed like a huge pity play for those sucked into the communist theology and what a god awful marriage his wife endured. Nolan missed the whole story. Really blew it on this one, sorry to say.

Review_Title: Overhyped! Kept waiting for movie to get good
Review: I walk out on very few movies and this was the third movie I have walked out on. I'm glad to hear I didn't miss much as the remaining 1.5 hours were the same. I kept asking myself when will the movie get good? This movie started reminding me about working with all the men in my field and how all of them want to be masters of the universe. There are no interesting characters. I would've enjoyed a movie about WW2 more. In fact, even Pearl Harbor was more enjoyable than this bore.

I think this is a massively overhyped, seriously underwhelming film which I am afraid I gave up on halfway through! Watching it was such a slog, I struggled to stay awake - and that doesn't happen to me!

Review_Title: Boring long movie with no action Do not believe the10 star reviews.
Review: Boring long movie with no action. Actors whisper for no reason. Lots un-interesting controversy among the scientists. If you do not know the story of how the war against Japan in WW2 was won then it may be interesting. Although, I have seen better and more gripping documentaries re-enacting this subject. They do not show the problems of their project. And the final act does not include the one thing that the thousands of people in WW2 were working to do. I think Nolan is living on his past reputation from his Batman movies. At three hours it is tedious for teenagers or anyone who likes action movies to watch.

Except Dunkirk ,
i am a die hard fan of Christopher Nolan . But this one was definitely going as the worst movie of Nolan. I get it it's a biographical drama . But I was never emotionally connected to any character , never invested in any character . Because if that this was one of the most boring movie i have ever watched in theaters.

I don't really get the hype. I find Nolan's movies to be unnecessarily complicated without a coherent plot to produce enough build up of any emotion. Movies that are not linear in timeline are for some reason perceived as smarter???

I am a big fan of Christopher Nolan's work, but this just didn't do it for me at all. Dialogue heavy and plain boring in parts, it was a very long winded and laboured journey. Frankly, I'm also starting to get fed up with the lack of female representation in his films.... I saw Barbie and that was much more enjoyable! I'm not saying the film isn't well shot, well acted, or has gravitas, but it was way, way overdone and so very long. When I went to the loo, I thought about having a coffee and going back to my partner when the film was further along. I hope his next film is better - I usually love his style, but not this!

Found the film very well made and all the actors played their parts brilliantly, but found it longer than it needed to be and boring overall to be completely honest. There was also too much back and forth in terms of what time it was. Cillian was in almost every single scene and was brilliant. May be a marmite movie and you either love it or hate it. I would still recommend people see it but I think it has been over hyped as I went in with high expectations expecting much more in the way of action but I would say there is only one small part of the film that could be classed as that sadly. Okay and that's it.

Review_Title: Not the best work from Nolan
Review: Had always been a fan of Nolan's works, but Oppenheimer certainly is not one of them. Here are my reasons.

I haven't seen a worse movie in at least five years, at every level scripting, directing,editing, production. Embarrassingly amateurish, boring, repetitive, incomprehensible, written for low-IQ viewers. Almost all dialogue and attention is drowned out by the worst film "music' ever composed - and entirely unsuited and unnecessary. An nsult to intelligence and taste. A very important true story is buried in the endless blathering hype and cutting. The acting is irrelevant and interchangeable. Even the sex scenes are extraneous, laughable and cold. No woman comes across as a credible character. The film attempts to offer a vision moral confusion and disgrace without the slightest concession made to the sequential clarity viewers expecting a 3-hour film.

One must assume that this is going to be fantastic given the credits' list of names. Your anticipation builds as you begin to watch it. Then you understand that it is unnecessarily dramatized, extremely long, and uninteresting.

No action, just talking heads and overly loud background music. Surprise surprise maybe a bomb goes off. Better of watching old videos about the MP on the Smithsonian website. Nakedness thrown in for no good purpose.

Too long and boring. Jumps all over the place from time to time and the viewers have no idea when something is happening and who's who. No mention of the horrific result after the bombing of Japan. The movie shows Oppenheimer like he's the victim here?? Two sex scenes and nudity that make zero sense to the story and don't fit into the style whatsoever. Three long hours and barely any mention about his private life. How did they get back their kid or how was he a "womanizer" exactly? The cherry on top is the guy who speaks with Russian (!!) accent when in fact he's playing a Hungarian.

I fed into all of the hype and was extremely excited to watch this film. I will never get these 3 hours of my life back. In my opinion there was only one good scene and that was the explosion. The rest of the film is a convoluted mess with all the characters shaping up to be completely uninteresting(except for Oppenheimer himself) The acting was rather good but it doesn't matter when the characters are uninteresting. I've seen many movies and I think this takes the cake for the movie that was the least gripping/entertaining. How can you be expected to pay attention to a 3 hour dialogue slog of a movie when you can barely hear the actors talking? I don't think it was a theatre issue but if it was I apologize. The film is only good for about 10 mins, 1/10 should have seen Barbie.

I was eager to watch "Oppenheimer" with high hopes of experiencing an engaging and insightful depiction of one of the most critical scientific figures in history. However, I was left deeply disappointed by the film, which fell far short of my expectations.
Not sure the hype around Oppenheimer. I am a fan of Nolan but his storytelling is somewhat strange. Timeline never flows properly and the movie likes to jump all around.

Review_Title: Is a movie good when you await the end of it?
Review: Oppenheimer is a film that tries to explore the life and work of the man behind the atomic bomb, but fails to deliver a compelling story or a satisfying conclusion. The film is too long, too slow, and too dense with technical and historical details that only a physics or politics student would appreciate. The characters are bland and unrelatable, the dialogue is dry and dull, and the cinematography is uninspired and boring. The film does not do justice to the complexity and controversy of Oppenheimer's legacy, nor does it offer any insight or emotion to the audience. Oppenheimer is a film that should have been left in the lab. One good scene which was impressive but left me very sober. It was anxiety inducing. Then 30 more minutes and I just hoped the movie will end. It's not just a "problem" with Oppenheimer but I noticed with other movies with similar running time. Even The Batman which I loved was slightly too long. Not exactly the same goes with Oppenheimer I felt like an editor and wanted to cut out the last 20 minutes. The movie could have ended on a more impressive note than it actually did. I also didn't really like Nolan's typical beige filter in it. The B/W segments felt refreshing. Weirdly my cinema's 70mm film projector went broke after 30 minutes in. (The first nude scene with Florence Pugh and Cillian Murphy). They talked about Freud and Jung and the movie was paused for 20 minutes, just to be replaced by the digital backup. That was an interesting experience. It was my first time seeing a movie in analog and I guess it was also a first time for a long time for the theater. It has its charms. The grain. The white flicker between cuts and the slight stroboscopic effect like a flip book. Anyways. That's all.

As a fervent devotee of Christopher Nolan's remarkable filmography, I found myself regrettably disenchanted by his latest venture, "Oppenheimer." My cinematic palate is one that appreciates complexity and richness, nurtured by Nolan's previous masterpieces like "Interstellar" and "Inception."

Review_Title: Wort movie I have ever seen. Wasted 3 hours of my life
Review: It seems like this movie has taken the art of confusion to a whole new level! It's as if the characters within it are participants in a grand scavenger hunt, desperately searching for the elusive plot that seems to be playing a game of hide-and-seek. In a world where the concept of a middle, an end, or even coherent dialogue seems optional, this film boldly embraces the unknown, treating viewers to a symphony of uncertainty and a parade of slo-mo scenes that could make a snail look speedy.

A three-hour-long movie, with over 80% of its plot centered around discussions at a table, filled with dialogues, not about how to make an atomic bomb, but entirely focused on politics and arguments, devoid of action sequences, and might even say, lacking a coherent storyline.

I saw OPPENHEIMER in 70-millimeter format. I wish I had liked it better, but I didn't. What I disliked most about it was the soundtrack. There was INCESSANT background noise that rumbled and roared and thudded (with a lot of Sensurround-style vibration) throughout the film. Sometimes it drowned out the actors, several of whom were hard for me to understand in the first place. The style of the photography was also off-putting. To make it seem like a documentary or a period-piece, sections of it were filmed in black-and-white or used filters to deaden the colors. I think all these gimmicks were there to disguise the fact that the script wasn't really very focused and was 3 hours long. The script is based on true historical events, and reality isn't easily shoehorned into a coherent plot. It was never clear to me exactly what the point was. There are a lot of good actors in this movie, but I didn't know who they were until I saw the credits! I still think of Matt Damon and Robert Downey Junior as young men, and they're NOT! I thought Downey gave the best performance in the film, though. The art direction and costume design seemed to accurately depict the period, although thanks to the cinematography, we'll never know what the true colors of anything were. (I wonder if the film-maker told these people that he was going to use stylized cinematography beforehand, or whether they found out when they saw the film.) I admire the film's ambition, and I think the issues it raises are things that people should think about, but I wonder if it would have been better if they had just told the story.

Review_Title: The other side of the Coin
Review: I am a Christopher Nolan fan, particularly drawn to his original works. Biography and real-life storytelling also intrigue me, which is why I'm quite familiar with the Oppenheimer story. Based on the trailers, I believed this movie would delve into the science of bomb-making and explore Oppenheimer's emotions. In an interview, Nolan himself stated that the movie revolves around Oppenheimer, with the supporting cast merely there to complement the main character.

I thinknthis movie is overhyped and overrated. It is just famous because is not the Barbie one, meme culture had to pick a movie to memerize and this one was dark and serious so lets conpare it to Barbie.
This movie is so borimg that it should be banned!

Where do I even begin with this trainwreck of a movie? "Openheimer" was supposed to be a cinematic masterpiece, exploring the fascinating life of J. Robert Oppenheimer and the development of the atomic bomb. However, it turned out to be an utter disappointment, leaving me questioning why I wasted my precious time and money on this cinematic catastrophe.

Review_Title: I want my ticket money back
Review: Worse than Tenet, feels like Nolan lost his capacity to direct, this time he definitely used stock imagery for the special effects in this film. Sound is even worse, you will leave the theatre with a constant high pitch in your ear. And let's not mention the dialogue wich is boring and repetitive. It cuts from one character to another and is more political than impressive. One more thing ...there are cheaper youtube documentaries on this subject that do a better job than this film. Hollywood's last breath and it smells like onions. I want my money back, don't be mislead by the "masterpiece" reviews, this belongs in the bin.

Oppenheimer from which I had expectations and waited for so long was more a documentary. 1/3rd black and white 1/3rd historical facts and 1/3rd indecipherable wannabe movie making trying to give it a drama masterpiece look. Movie lovers think it was a documentary, documentary lovers think it was a movie. In my opinion total hodgepodge to confuse but would definitely break the bank. Acting was weak, even though resemblances matter but poor acting would only earn and not be long lasting as a movie to be reckoned with. In short a documovie would be the right word instead of entertainment. A solid 3/10 from me.

Review_Title: You can't have dramatic scenes if all scenes are dramatic
Review: Hate to say it, but the movie is quite bad. I usually really enjoy Nolan's work but this one is lacking any redeemable characteristics. The main issue is that it is boring. The story itself is interesting but the way it is presented is dull. It felt like 3 hour long trailer. Every scene had to be dramatic with over the top dramatic music and dialog. And when you have only dramatic scenes you don't have any dramatic scenes. Even the explosion lacked any actual effect. The only dramatic thing about it was that we had some 30 seconds of quietness. The movie had that stupid dramatic music non-stop. NON-STOP! The actors were fine, put the script was lackluster and I think the cast, the music, all the drama and the way the story was presented was because they knew the scrips was bad. Also I don't know who that movie targets. I feel like years ago history movies targeted people who would appreciate them and because they were done with a lot of love to the story, attention to details and made interesting they were appealing not only to history buffs. Nowadays historical movies target everybody so they are no longer historical but exaggerated dramas that are only inspired loosely by history. The movie really sucks.

Review_Title: Wanted it to be good but it is not
Review: My first review ever on here. And its is a warning. This movie is terrible.

Review_Title: Boring, there's nothing more i can say.
Review: I went to this movie with maybe too high expectations. I loved Nolan's work so far, with Interstellar as my all time favorite movie. Seeing the ratings and read the user reviews i really thought this couldn't go wrong.

Review_Title: Boring, loud, choppy, bad direction, did I say boring?
Review: The entire time I felt as if script was torn into small pieces and the director decided to film it while he glued back together all the parts like puzzles.

The expectations that go into a Nolan film have obviously affected the end product of most of his more recent efforts, so much so that the great potential story of one of the most significant technological events in history becomes poorly told.

98% of the 3-hour long movie was talking, interrogating, flashing back and forth and some unnecessary sex scenes. Didn't show the bomb making process, how it was used, the aftermath. Yes of course I can Goggle for my own interest but that was the impression from all the hype and false advertising from this movie! The movie was super boring I couldn't wait for it to be over! Also Lewis Strauss played by Robert Downey Jr. Was very annoying, guy kept fixing his tie, button / unbutton and putting on and taking off his jacket, so pretentious! I regret taking my whole family to see this hyped up movie! Don't fall for this hype and this is definitely not appropriate for teens and younger.

Oppenheimer might be a decent movie somewhere under all that noise but I put in earplugs (I came prepared: it's a Christopher Nolan movie) and often put my hands over my ears as well. Nevertheless, with the cranked-up volume in movie theaters these days, I had no problem following the dialog.

Review_Title: How is this movie a masterpiece????
Review: I can't believe these other positive reviews are they for real? I feel like I'm reading the onion. This movie should have been great but it is too long. For context, I'm a fan of history and WWII, but this was difficult to follow. The storyline is convoluted with too many plot lines. It desperately needed to be edited and the movie felt endless after a while. I felt like I was kidnapped in that theater.
The week before I watched a documentary on TV about Oppenheimer so I new about his turbulent and interesting life. Was curious to see how Nolan dramatized it.

Review_Title: Very good acting, but nothing else
Review: Not gonna say it was a bad movie. But it was average at best. Despite the amazing acting, the movie falls short in every other aspect. The short scenes and continuous cutting and shifting from past to future where some scenes didn't serve any purpose or help to understand in fact it makes you more lost alongside the unnecessary characters. All of the previous added the 40-50 extra minutes that made it a boring film. Disappointed mainly because of the hype around it. But honestly a movie mainly about "bombs" had 1 bomb scene, and 90% was just meetings of people grilling each other with load music in the background.

This film falls well short of a perfect 10. Undoubtedly, it boasts commendable acting, a decent soundtrack, and an intriguing subject. Yet, regrettably, it devolves into a borefest, burdened by an overtly complicated plot. The story's conclusion seems within reach, but it cunningly extends for another hour, prolonging the viewer's endurance. While the performances shine, the movie's charm wears thin amidst the convoluted narrative. Honest enjoyment gets clouded by an unnecessary length, leaving one longing for a more concise, satisfying experience. In essence, it has potential, but its shortcomings overshadow its strengths.

Cillian did well, but it wasn't a groundbreaking performance. It was his normal character minus a little of his edginess that he always plays. He did well, but nothing extraordinary. The plot was interesting until Oppy's sabotage plot because it left facts and dove healing into speculative history, and, forgive me, I'm not a communist sympathizer and wound up walking out due to the love and perfection ceremony for communism... the right kind, not the soviet kind that's actually bad... because there's a difference, right? The actual explosion could've been epic, but, in imax, it fell short. I liked the first half of the movie, but it wasn't great. As a history major and buff it was good, but definitely not an 8. Especially if you like facts.

The good parts? The acting, top notch. The story itself is also very important and interesting, but it was told in an awfully bad way and very slow progression of main storyline. It is NOT worth watching in the cinema, there is very poor usage of sound effects. It's just loud for no reason. Only the bomb effect was great, but rest is just very loud noise for no good reason and you just don't want to hear at it full blast when people are clapping or similar loud noises. It provides absolutely no effect other than you want to close your ears. Also bad cinematography, random use of white/black coloring for no good reason. It's not used as flashback there is no consistency of using white/black here and there it's just random and doesn't make the film anymore interesting, completely unnecessary. IMO the worst film Christopher Nolan has produced so far. If not for amazing acting, I would've left the cinema. 3 hours used to tell a story that could EASILY have been boiled down to 1,5 hours. 30-40% of the movie is about an interrogation that has real consequense or impact to the audience, it just seems like an awful long waste of time because. Some guy felt leftout so he decided to run a cross examination of Oppenheimer, which leads to nothing except he can't have his security clearance re-approved. Why would you Nolan spent 40% of the film on this utterly boring part? I honestly beats me how people can enjoy this movie. I would rather watch a black and white documentary on the manhatten project then my hearing would be intact and I would be more informed and less filled with nonsense.

Review_Title: Most Overrated movie in the history of Hollywood
Review: This movie is a complete disgrace to cinema lovers or to history buffs.

This movie was LOUSY. The scenes were ALL too dark, as in not bright enough to see much. The sound was not always clear. There were way too many characters to keep track of. We didn't know who these people were supposed to be. The time that events took place was all jumbled up. There was much to much jumping back and forth in time. The characters all looked alike. The physics information was geared towards 2nd graders. Sex scene at the hearing? Why was there a need to show naked bodies out of context? There was no focus - The bomb story, the science, the wife and girlfriend relationships, the hearings, background stories, the communist angle, Los Alamos. Too much touching on something a little bit but not enough.

Review_Title: Instead of watching a film about Oppenheimer I was watching a film about Christopher Nolan.
Review: Christopher Nolan has been a favourite of mine. However his recent obsession with trying to maintain some unnecessary reputation for a particular style of writing is more about him than the films. He doesnt pay any attention to the story hes telling he is more focused on trying to prove something by using a senseless non linear style of storytelling that adds no value to the story whatsoever. Watching a Christopher Nolan film nowadays is just like watching a self portrait of himself. It doesn't have anything to do with the story or the film. Making both the story and the film unentertaining, unmemorable and boring.

Review_Title: 6 stars is pretty disappointing for Nolan's movie.
Review: Christopher Nolan's latest directorial effort left me with mixed feelings. The screenplay and scriptwriters fell short, resulting in a convoluted and confusing narrative. Despite Nolan's attempts to overdo things, the weak foundation couldn't support the complexity. The music lacked a thematic connection to the storyline, leaving the overall experience underwhelming. While the film showcased impressive visuals and cinematography, it couldn't compensate for its flaws. A five-star rating for technical prowess, but the execution fell flat, leaving me wanting more from this talented director. Hoping for a better show next time around.

Review_Title: It's a typical Oscar movie - boring!
Review: The movie is okay. Wasted in IMAX. The music production is at best, oppressive, intrusive and a distraction from what are great actors doing their thing. The script might have multiple layers but it lacks conflict, an inciting incident and a meaningful resolution. It's linear, which biopics tend to be, but it's not a 'story'. Flawed genius? Perhaps or just an unfaithful man - not ground breaking and it lacked a real reason to 'be'. It might have been better if Heisenberg and Oppenheimer were enemies instead of friends or some personal conflict existed that resulted in a winner. Here the movie falls flat and tries to use over bearing music to fill a void left by a lifeless underdramatic script.
It's a redundant biography without focus, rather than a movie. It includes so many details that I don't know what's the point. Or perhaps Biography movie is not my type. And it is way too long!

A self-important movie, you'd be a social outcast if you diss it. But it deserves dissing. What is with filmmakers these days that they forget we need people to root for in a movie, even one based on the winners' version of history. Technical filmmaking is okay but people need people to connect to a piece of film.
After having seen the high ratings, the interviews with the cast and the trailer, I was looking forward to see an accurate depiction of an important part of history, still shaping our world today.

Robert Oppenheimer... so many stories! Let me tell them all! That seems to be the thinking by director Christopher Nolan, whose directing principles do not include "kill your darlings". Not judging by this three hour, oh so slow movie containing a ridiculous number of talking heads.

Review_Title: Worst movie I've ever seen in cinema
Review: There were many things that made the movie not as good as I expected: poor writing, non-immersive acting from most characters & non-stop ear-deafening sounds among others.

Review_Title: It was three hours long...but it seemed like...three hours...
Review: The movie was three hours long...and it seemed longer. I was looking forward to seeing an adult movie, but spend three hours watching a grey movie with ugly cinematography and didn't even notice the much talked about black and white photography, because it didn't contrast with the bland grey of the rest of the film. There was a big deal about it being filmed in IMAX, but it remind3d me of watching 8mm home movies, of a family you don't know, or really care to get to know.

2.5 hours of torture. Enjoyed only 30 minutes of science discussion. Whole movie was based on countries ideological battle. US thinks communism is bad for everyone and it will destroy humanity. US centric approach is always right, that's what they think. Whole movie is based on useless group discussions multiple times. Very well promoted. Boring and pathetic dialogues. I was feeling sleepy after 1 hour. Don't know why they wasted 3 hours on a topic which could be covered in a 15-30 minutes of short description. I feel Christopher Nolan wasted money and resources on such short topic which we can read within 15 minutes.

Was bored in first hour and stopped watching it pretty much boring and hard to follow It was not as dope as I thought it could be i didn't enjoy watching it especially for 3 hours straight seems impossible i recommend watching chernobyl instead it was far more impressive whereas i ended up reading a wikipedia page rather than wasting 2 more hours for nonsense
Was bored in first hour and stopped watching it pretty much boring and hard to follow It was not as dope as I thought it could be i didn't enjoy watching it especially for 3 hours straight seems impossible i recommend watching chernoby instead it was far nore impressive whereas i ended up reading a wikipedia page rather than wasting 2 more hours for nonsense.

Review_Title: Oh Nolan :( - You either die a hero, or live long enough to see yourself become the villain
Review: I want to say I am a massive Nolan fan and there is still a seedling of hope within me that we will get the chance to watch another masterpiece before I pass off the earth, however, I think those days are sadly gone.

Review_Title: Incredibly overrated and an absolute snooze fest.
Review: Sorry, but I just don't understand the overwhelming positive reviews. I am a fan of Nolan, but this movie was just a complete miss.

Review_Title: Oppenheimer: A Monumental Misfire in Nolan's Oeuvre
Review: "Oppenheimer," Christopher Nolan's ambitious adaptation of "American Prometheus," disappointingly falls short of expectations set by his previous cinematic marvels. The film is certainly monumental, but its expansive 3-hour length proves testing for the audience's patience. We anticipate a compelling narrative around scientific discovery, atomic theory, and the birth of the atomic bomb. Instead, Nolan swerves into a labyrinth of political intrigue, painting a shadowy picture of Oppenheimer as a communist.

Review_Title: Beyond dull... from what I saw
Review: I was so excited for this film. We had to walk out after an hour, which felt like two. Every scene was about 20 seconds, you had no time to digest what was happening or why and who any of the smaller characters were. One minute he's in a classroom the, next he's in the desert on a horse. Parties, classroom, back on a horse. WHY!?! It did seem like the film was slowing down when he was recruited for the Manhattan Project but by that point I'd lost all faith in the film. Maybe when it finally hits Netflix or something I'll start it again from where I left but that was one of the worst hours of cinema I've ever witnessed. Even the dialogue felt rushed like they knew it was pointless so they just wanted to get through it. How about just not including it?

Review_Title: A failed attempt of history or story telling
Review: The movie has such a great scope to tell relevance of events, story of a human being, story of a conspiracy, story of science, story of relationships, story of nuclear reaction, story of atom bomb, none of which is a selected topic of the movie.

Review_Title: Big fan of nolan.. From india.. But totally disappointed
Review: As a big fan of nolan, must confess the moviebwas boring.. Screenplay was all about to prove openhiemer innocent

It's so terrible and doesn't get better with time...Such a disappointment from Nolan. They could've made it much much shorter because the movie is sooo slow. The dialogues are so cringey and bad. The only good thing about this movie is cinematography. The acting is okay but since the whole plot of the movie is really bad it oftentimes comes off as cringey. I really recommend you not to watch this movie because you will only waste your money and time but also your IQ level. There are many unnecessary nudity and sex scenes as well. I was really looking forward to this, so I am very sad to write this.

When it was good it was amazing but those occasional 20 mins of nothing just made it draaaaaagg but i saw another review say there were 3 really great scenes (you'll know the ones once you watch them) and how they're incredible but overall despite the scenes it went on for too long completely. 3 hours which essentially was 1 hour of incredible cinema and 2 of just confusing timelines, millions of physicists who all blend into one and florence pugh having 2 s** scenes and a slewer slide scene (really weird she actually took on the role tbh) but yeah prefered barbie tbh and ik shouldn't be compared but marketing really messed up releasing on same day so not really my fault! And befor letterboxd nerds say that barbie was just dopamine enjoyable and just cuz oppenheimer isn't constant fun doesn't mean it's worse : no! Ur wrong and idc.

Awful. Nolan is LOST. 2 hours and 40 minutes of meaningless dialogue, abrupt cutaways, nameless, empty characters and 20 minutes of real movie making/story telling. Robert Oppenheimer is an interesting, impactful figure in history, but clearly not worthy of a movie about his life if this is what we get. I cannot believe a master like Nolan can take such a juicy subject and turn it into the most tedious endurance tests one will ever face in a movie theatre. If you're interested in the Manhattan project you'll get a glimpse of it. If you're interested in seeing a two and a half hour interrogation into whether or not Robert Oppenheimer had communist ties whooo boy are you in for a treat. Cillian Murphy was fine. Nolan needs to find himself ASAP.

Review_Title: Inappropriately loud and fast paced for what should have been a quiet boardroom drama
Review: So I'll take the contrarian view here and say Oppenheimer is basically kind of bad. I don't think we'd be seeing these sorts of reviews if the movie was promoted or hyped up less. Very sad but true. I did my best to conceal my serious disappointment while I was at the theatre, didn't want to seem a party pooper. I went to the theater hoping I was going to be watching a genuine revival of Hollywood or something along those lines- that I would lean away from speed, colour, and volume, just a little bit back towards pacing, character, narrative. I understand it is a blockbuster film, I was just hoping the needle would move somewhat in the other direction of the general trend in a film such as this. No such luck.

In 25+ years of seeing movies at the movie theater have I left a movie early. The only good thing about this movie, was the acting and the wardrobe. The screenplay sucked. Made it about sex. Romanticized science. I couldn't even make it to the actual explosion. This film was pure propaganda at its finest. What a waste of money. If you do happen to go see this movie just be prepared to be underwhelmed. I saw the movie last night in imax. Why this was in imax I don't understand. The glasses did nothing. Hollywood is officially DEAD. Flaming pile of garbage. From Nolan too!?!?!? Would not recommend.

I don't know how I sat in the theatre for 3 hours I was dying for this movie to finish. Very boring and long, just not my type of movies. The acting was great however I don't like when there is this kind of jumps between scenes. The whole story wasn't so clear for me, if my husband didn't explain that for me I wouldn't get any single idea about the whole movie lol. The most important part which was about the boom was so short while the focus was on other things like him sleeping with a woman then having an affair with her later etc.

Oppenheimer felt like a VERY long trailer because of very short scenes and a constant blaring soundtrack. A insane amount of details and names were thrown at you, while almost every single scene has a score playing. It only got interesting about 2/3rds into the film, but by then it was too late to save the overall experience - at least for me.

"Oppenheimer" is about nebulous men struggling with identity. We're told that the problem is morality, but the finished film - the sum total of Christopher Nolan's vision, script, direction, and ego (so much ego) - has little to say about the catastrophic technology it supposedly chronicles. It barely registers as a biopic, and it certainly isn't a meditation on history or even the bomb. Instead, it's three hours of a director insisting that he has something important to say, but that you should be smart enough to understand what that is without him having to accomplish it.

Nolan has promoted the movie around the theme of atomic bomb stressing the significance of watching it only in imax theatres. But in reality besides a 10 minute scene of bomb detonation, there is nothing in the movie to hold your interest. Its literally the biggest scam of a movie. People have paid 3-4X of the price to watch this movie on imax but they all left infuriated at the end. Its 3 hours of people engaging in conversations - literal torture. Dude movies are meant for entertainment not to listen to boring dialogues. I honestly slept in the last 1 hour and i missed nothing. This is not only Nolans weakest film but the most boring film to come out in the last many years.

This is one of the most tedious boring fims I have seen in a long time. 3 hours was about 21/2 hours too long. Unless you actually knew the history you would not be much wiser. How many people know how thermonuclear fission and fusion work and why it was so important. Odd bits were good but the constant jumping about was annoying. The casting was stereotyped although the actors did the best they could in the circumstances. And why did the sound have to be so deafening? The visual effects were cliched. Real pictures of an atomic bomb going off are dramatic enough without the swirling clouds. PS I hated Dunkirk too so I guess I am in the minority. I yearn for the days of cinema when there was a good story, well told and well acted. David Lean where are you? (I gues that gives my age away!)

Review_Title: Two Years too early to use the AI dilemma as a modern metaphor
Review: This Movie is overrated. Yes, the Cast is Top notch. Yes, the Score and the visuals are good.
Dont waste time watching, the whole cinema were sleeping , its too long , too boring, no story, streteched for nothing, every moment you are waiting for something to happen.

Review_Title: I may need to watch it again
Review: This movie being shot in 70mm IMAX film doesn't make any sense once I watched it, the movie itself isn't very cinematic. Additionally the film throws around so many names and characters it makes it very hard to follow dialogue and story. I walked out being confused and a little underwhelmed. Near the end, the movie will lose most of the audience with all of the concepts, characters and lawsuits style scenes the last for a third of the movie. Personally the movie got worse and worse, with looser plot and story as it went. The one thing I well give Nolan is the sound design and ost, so goddamn good, it's my favorite part. Lastly, it felt like the whole movie revolved and written around the ending quote in the movie.

Review_Title: Another Nolan Debacle - Don't Waste Your Time
Review: After Tenet I swore I would never watch another Nolan film. But I went to see this because of all the hype. Big mistake. Same old crappy storytelling, audio issues, and confusing time jumping from Mr. Nolan.
Review for Oppenheimer

"Oppenheimer" disappoints with lackluster cinematography, bland dialogue and a poorly written screenplay. The visuals lack depth, leaving viewers detached, while wooden dialogue fails to engage. Moreover, "Oppenheimer" perpetuates the narrative of male hegemony, while women appear briefly and unnecessarily naked on screen.

Let me talk about the good sides first: The acting was great, except for one person. Now let's get to the bad sides, there are plenty of it: It was a movie that made you tired while watching the movie, but it was not like the brainstorming after watching Inception, it was like Avatar 2 (you can understand if you watched the movie) and it was far from using its time efficiently and it was also not interesting. There were too many unnecessary scenes, for example, the scene where Oppenheimer's sex life is told. Emily Blunt put on bad acting. The actor who performed so well in A Quiet Place did nothing but irritate me here. But I loved the character very much, everything would have been much better if Robert had listened to him and I liked his tactical intelligence. At some moments it seemed to me that he didn't know what the hell he was doing and what he wanted to be. The editing got messed up anyway. He should stop working with Jennifer Lame immediately. Long story short, the movie is not satisfying at all and it is full of strange details from top to bottom. But of course, everyone adores Christopher Nolan, so he will get 9 10 from everywhere in this movie (see: Dunkirk, Teneth the dialogue was not very important in this movie, as well as the dialogue in Dunkirk, which is very disgusting. Either you skip it or it will be shown as details that are not so important by trying it as RDJ. However, this movie was only a 3 hour Wikipedia page for me. To me, it was nothing more than a better scripted and Nolan version of Avatar 2, Oppenheimer. Instead, I prefer to watch Barbie or MI:8 for the 2nd or 3rd time. 1/10.

Review_Title: There is first in every thing.
Review: There is first in every thing.

Being a huge Nolan fan(Interstellar is my favourite movie of all time) I had so high expectations going in the cinema for this one...oh boy was I disappointed! It was partly my fault,having listened to all the praise..masterpiece here..best biopic movie ever there..all the hype was created. For what? For a movie that just feels like a series of trailers with the music and the score,instead of being complimentary to the film and create such an important vibe throughout all Nolan film ,it ended being so distracting..always like keeping you on the edge of your seat like something important will happen. But it never does,it is just endless boring,complicated and hard to follow dialogue after dialogue. There are so many characters in the movie that you just do not care for..I didnt care what hapoens to Oppenheimer himself,Emily Blunt..Robert Downey jr.... Sure,they are great actors,but there is nothing to root for the characters they play..

I don't dislike many films but this one was awful. The score was completely overwhelming and constant, to the point where you couldn't hear most of the dialogue. There were two trials where the only thing at stake was seemingly a loss of reputation. There was hours and hours of talking and the constant introduction of white male characters who all looked the same. I felt as if I'd been in a ten hour long lecture when I left the cinema. The only good part was when they did the bomb test in the middle of the film. The two halves before and after that are dreary, pretentious and overwhelming for your ears.

Review_Title: "A heap of broken images" - Good idea, poorly executed
Review: Bad writing, Overwrought music, Chaotic story structure full of indistinguishable characters, Bad makeup and wigs, Self-important, Heavy-handed. Too many unintentionally laughable moments. Should be the story of the century but came out as shallow arrogant claptrap. Taking a story of this magnitude and meaning and rendering it hollow is a feat unto itself. Like a bad collage - "a heap of broken images" - all the pieces are there but just throwing them up against the wall in random order and hoping they stick does not result in a meaningful work of art, even if you have your leading man hold a copy of The Wasteland toward the beginning of your film. Why didn't someone tell Nolan he was on the wrong path here? Where were his friends?

First time I've ever nodded off in a cinema. Firstly, the film is WAY too long. The characters are pretty much universally unlikeable and it is chock full of meandering wramblings from the McCarthy era mascinations.
Oppenheimer could have been a great movie. The problem is the script is weak. It's hard to understand and the jumping around in time gets confusing.
After an hour I told my friend "I think the movie is starting now". My friend and I left before the end, we had enough.

Review_Title: 3 hours of my life pretty much wasted.
Review: Actually saying I wasted 3 hours of my life is a bit harsh. This movie did hold my attention for most of the time and I only dozed off once. Perhaps if I had been more prepared and brushed up on my history, it would probably have been better. I had absolutely no idea who most of the people were or what their actual significance was, politically or otherwise. I'm a bit embarrassed that I didn't know more about them as I am 67 years old and my dad served overseas in WW2. I went to see the movie with three friends who are in their 70's and I don't believe they got much if any more out of it than I did. It was a very disappointing movie for all of us.

Well made film. In all manners just fantastic. Nolan is exceptional. When Hollywood is taking itself out with politics instead of entertainment, Nolan saved the day and brought us a spectacle. As good as I hoped it would be. Fairly accurate story telling but very much biased. Here's how.
The movie was really bad.

Let me talk about the good sides first: The acting was great, except for one person. Now let's get to the bad sides, there are plenty of it: It was a movie that made you tired while watching the movie, but it was not like the brainstorming after watching Inception, it was like Avatar 2 (you can understand if you watched the movie) and it was far from using its time efficiently and it was also not interesting. There were too many unnecessary scenes, for example, the scene where Oppenheimer's sex life is told. Emily Blunt put on bad acting. The actor who performed so well in A Quiet Place did nothing but irritate me here. But I loved the character very much, everything would have been much better if Robert had listened to him and I liked his tactical intelligence. At some moments it seemed to me that he didn't know what the hell he was doing and what he wanted to be. The editing got messed up anyway. He should stop working with Jennifer Lame immediately. Long story short, the movie is not satisfying at all and it is full of strange details from top to bottom. But of course, everyone adores Christopher Nolan, so he will get 9 10 from everywhere in this movie (see: Dunkirk, Teneth the dialogue was not very important in this movie, as well as the dialogue in Dunkirk, which is very disgusting. Either you skip it or it will be shown as details that are not so important by trying it as RDJ. However, this movie was only a 3 hour Wikipedia page for me. To me, it was nothing more than a better scripted and Nolan version of Avatar 2, Oppenheimer. Instead, I prefer to watch Barbie or MI:8 for the 2nd or 3rd time. 6/10.

This was a birthday present from my wife, i can't believe i sat through this rubbish. WHY...1. The music was so over powering it didn't fit in with the film. 2. Extremely slow going, lots of talking. 3. Flicks from one scene to another couldn't make heads or tails of it. 4. Didn't like the sex scenes, didn't need it. 5. The film was way way too long. 6. Some of the acting was SO wooden, my nan could've done better, and she's been dead for 20 years. 6. The story could've been told in a much better way..maybe make it abit more entertaining understanding enjoyable....what we need is Steven Spielberg back.

Oppenheimer is an ambitious movie, a well-made movie, but simply put, it's not a great movie. Historically, science and politics have always been a rough mix, and this biographical movie covers all the bases. Oppenheimer is a complex person with a unique intelligence that, during wartime, makes him a hot property. But his politics come back into play throughout the story, especially post-bomb. The acting is solid, but not exactly living up to the raves I've read and heard. The casting is pretty good, except for the bizarre Harry Truman scene. Overall, it's good, dialogue-heavy, three hours of biographical drama that probably would work just as well on Netflix as the big screen. It did not quite fulfill my expectations.
I try to be honest and consistent with my opinions. I believe in critical thinking and I hope it is not a dying skill.

Damn, I wanted to love this. I love almost everything Nolan does. But part of the reason I love him is because he's so creative and rarely needs to resort to gratuitous female nudity to make his point. He's better than that. Not here. Could've removed the scenes of Florence's tits and wouldn't have changed one ounce of the story. No reason to include that other than laziness and appeasing men.

Review_Title: They made a great story in history extremely boring
Review: The history of story is truly fascinating! Yet the movie is drab, unexciting and stays at the same level of uninterst the whole way through the movie.

The movie is boring, too long, pompous... There were some monets where I was genuinely interested. However the overall imoression is a big dissapointment. They must have spent a lot on marketing to get so many people into cinema. I cant belive all the reviews praising this move as some kind of mastery. Seriously? Please take some reality check. It didnt even pass Bachdel test, we have 2023. There were also women working on the bomb. Oppenheimers wife almost isnt portrayed. Solely old male perspective. I would watch this movie on a Sunday, after lunch, layong on my couch and napping from time to time... Please do your own thinking, use your brain to formulate your own opinion. Uou find it boring but still give it 9 or 10 stars. Why? Because the mainstream tell you its a great masterpiece.

I honestly start believing that critics are bought once I see this one with a highscore. Nolan told us that we should watch it on a specific theater only to see 90% of a really lenghty movie being dining rooms and boring political/military inquest. There is no sense of real danger in the whole movie, the script feels really flat and uninteresting and it's hard to empathise with the main character when we have over a dozen of other characters revolving around him. Robert Downey Jr's entire plot is tedious and they try to give out some sort of plot twist around him that does not work well and there is also unnecessary nudity that I thought had died in the 00s. Worst work from Nolan, easily. I grant you one thing if you're going to risk wasting your time on the theaters one thing: boredom.

Great story. Great expectations . Awful cinematography. Badly told story. The interesting and important parts interrupted by endless awful music and loud pointless explosions and noises interrupting the dialog which would've made the movie good. To much going on at once in an uncontrolled chaos of epileptic visual display . The music for this movie was incredibly poor. Any part of the movie that I can think of , be that visual sound or story , was always eclipsed by unexplained chaotic take over by something else. If it's a story then music. If it's a scenery then epileptic display. Never thought I'll make it though. Bad experience.
"Tell don't show" boring . Required better writing, removing the entire story-line of security clearance.

Review_Title: Very intellectually oriented and Boring for regular audience
Review: Its only for people who understands and are seriously involved. If you want to watch a movie to relax or get entertained this is not such movie. That bomb scene is like 10 secs and whole drama is vey boring. Another disappointment of directors movie. Like the movie tenet what the hello is going on there...similar feeling... get to the point took looong and the drama feels like I watching a documentary. But Robert and Murphy were good especially in scenes towards the end. All the enthusiasm on watching the bomb scene lasted barely 10secs and is not even a big scene... It's like any other bomb in any other movie..

I had been waiting to see this for a month and finally was able to have time to see it. I have just enough knowledge to know who Oppenheimer was but didnt know the full story behind him. There was constant time hopping and so many substories within the main story I couldn't keep track of what and why all these were relevant. Not to mention tons of characters and no idea how they were related to what was happening or their importance. As someone who is interested in learning about history I really tried to hang with it and just couldn't. Maybe different editing would help, definitely less time hopping and more information on the characters. Hoping someone remakes this with clearer overall definition.

Review_Title: Floppenheimer: Atomic weapons? The Russians do it better.
Review: So many western bots leaving 10 star reviews here.

The film was, similar to TENET before, so overloaded with the soundtrack that one was permanently under tension, although 90% of the film consisted only of dialogues that didn't need any sound background. There was jumping back and forth between characters and temporal events without further explanation and a chronological order, so that one lost the connection at some point. The film couldn't decide which story to tell: the life story of Oppenheimer, the anti-communist movements in the U. S. government, or the development of the atomic bomb.

I have really liked all of Christopher Nolan's movies so far, but I guess that had to end sometime. This movie is dreadful. If you think Oppenheimer's atomic creation is the biggest bomb you've ever seen, this movie will prove you wrong.
This is an extremely pathetic movie.... Christopher Nolan has lost his touch. Is he brain dead to show Bhagwad Gita in a sex scene. Do indians mean so less for Nolan in his mind?

I had hoped to see more information regarding the creation of the explosives. For instance, I was positive that the movie would include the dragon's tail being tickled, yet it was not even mentioned. I was expecting for a movie with stuff like that. Do a search for Slotin, Daghlian, and tickling the dragon's tail if you are unfamiliar with this. In order to see what happens immediately before criticality, Slotin essentially moved two hemispheres of nuclear material slightly closer to one another. Oops! I know, big blunder. These events, I presume, weren't included since the majority of the movie had already ended by the time they occurred, which was after Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
